title: Best Velcro-Attached Bike Mirror text: I have no available space directly to the right of my left e-bike handle bar grip to attach a mirror. I did not want to cut a hole into the end of the grip. This left me just one available option....this mirror which attaches to the end of the grip with velcro.

The velcro does hold the end quite solidly onto the grip. The mirror itself is easy to adjust.

It's not a perfect mirror by any means. Even after tightening the ring, the mirror's position can still move if going over lots of bumps. With mirrors that stick out straight like this one does, it's easy to bump it. However, if this mount-type is your only option, it is the best and it does allow you to see behind you. I highly recommend this for people that have the same scenario as I have.

We have already had a good time with it. It is fun to compete with - who can go farthest, fastest, backwards, etc. Any kids that visit always want to try it. When the weather improves, it will be fairly simple to take outside. Although by then, he may want a traditional slackline

It is expensive but it is a quality product and with Amazon - it includes free shipping.

title: Makes Exercise Fun!
text: I joined Weight Watchers about 6 weeks ago. I have never been a fan of exercise, but this looked different. I have been using this regularly for at least the last month and I absolutely love it!!! This is a game changer! I have a Fitbit Alta that I got for Christmas. If I don't get a minimum of 250 steps in per hour, it buzzes a reminder for me to get up and move. I can twist on this for a few minutes and reach my hourly Fitbit goal. I also get on this first thing in the morning to give my steps a boost. I can earn about 1000 steps in about ten minutes or so. I rotate between twists and rocking back and forth. I weigh over 200 pounds and have not had any issues with cracking or breaking. I also have not had any problems with me knees when using it. The first few times I used it, I ended up turning in circles. It took me a while to get that under control and now I tend to stay in the same spot for most of my use. My husband made fun of me when I first started using it, but now he gets on it while playing games on the x-box. I have learned that I need to wear shoes or go barefoot when using it. It's too slippery when wearing just socks. Since I have joined Weight Watchers, I have lost 19 pounds. I believe that the Simply Fit Board has definitely helped me regarding my activity level.

title: Nice bottle (with a wonderful blue color!) text: I like this bottle for a few reasons. First of all, it looks great, duh. Second of all, I really like that it comes with 2 lids, 3 straws, and a cleaning brush (!). The brush is great because I've had a few straws get gross because I couldn’t clean them beyond running soapy water through them.

Physically, it is comfortable to hold and the koozie is a nice touch as well. I've taken this bottle to work out with a few times, and it keeps my water cold for hours (I haven't tested it with warm liquids). I'd recommend this bottle.

title: Great bag a little hard to put together but worth it.
text: Let me start off saying we got it way before their recommend delivery day. So that was a nice treat when things have been arriving late constantly. As for the boxes they arrived in the bag was a little on the heavy side but not too much. The base was extremely light and they each arrived on seperate days like they said. As for putting it together you will need 2 people. There is no way one person could do it. It wasn't difficult but the way it has to put together one person has to hold it while the other bolts it to the base. Once you get it together if your going to fill it with one or the other you should definitely fill it with sand. When you go to buy the sand it will take 2 fifty pound bags. It will take a while filling it because the hole is small. Just make sure you have it where you want it because your not moving it once it is. I would definitely recommend this bag to anyone that wants to get in shape by beating the snot out of a bag. Or if you have a teenager with a lot of pent up anger and is stuck in the house due to pandemic that is ravaging the globe. Either or would be great or both would be the best.

title: a tight "dialed" scooter for riders smaller than teens text: This scooter is slightly smaller than other "pro" scooters that accommodate teens and adults. My 9 year old has ridden the larger scooters and didn't seem to have a problem, but is more comfortable with the slightly lower and narrower bars on this scooter. The deck is a little narrower too, but still about the same width as a Razr A (but much shorter)

The scooter is built like a "pro" scooter, with a extruded deck, welded truss to the headstock which has a high-tensile (not chromoly) steel fork, a Internal Hidden Compression (IHC) headset which is the same as "HIC." The bars are chromoly (not aluminum). After getting the bars clamped on, a drop test showed this scooter is "dialed."

Here's a few shortcomings: The brake is composite (plastic) instead of steel. The fork is hi-ten steel instead of chromoly or 6061 Aluminum. The bars are chromoly which might be heavier than Aluminum or Titanium bars but they're still awesome. These things combine to make this scooter less expensive than typical "complete" pro scooters which seem to start around one-hundred fifty dollars and go up to several hundred dollars or more.

One problem I ran into was the bar clamp was not threaded completely through. So the bolts would bottom out on on the far-side of the clamp. I couldn't tighten them any further and almost damaged them trying to. I confirmed everything else was correct by using a clamp from another scooter. Then I had to use an 8mm x 1.25 tpi tap to finish threading the clamp. Once the clamp was threaded all the way through, it clamped the bars onto the fork just fine.

Since the scooter is new, I can't comment on how the bearings and wheels hold up yet. So far, so good.

Seasoned players, like the ones from my team, were not big fans and their main complaint was that the ball was just too light and they felt like "it wouldn't come back down" comparing it to a balloon of sorts.

The material and make of it is pretty good but the leather is a bit on the cheaper side. As i said I can't see seasoned players using this one, they will in a pinch but for the most part I can recommend this ball for beginners and also kids.

title: Sweet new scooter for my wife text: Christmas morning, I won, I had the biggest present under (actually beside) the tree; it's about time, this old girl works hard around here. Outside was a mess, fog, cold, but I put my LaScoota through the paces. A zig to the right, a zag to the left, I could feel it, the air warmed and sun shone down on my rosy cheeks. I was alive and free, nothing but the purr of new wheels on tarmac. All of this was of course shattered when my daughter flagged me down and swiped my new ride. "Oh, look at me mom", bah, it should be me out there. There are no witnesses, so I'm soon back at the helm and thinking I should put some distance between me and Santa's-little-helper.

title: Well thought out; some tools may never be used, but a few will prove essential text: I received this as a free review sample. For some reason I am drawn to survival kits such as this. The two most useful tools (to me) are the fire starter and the saw. However, in a true survival situation everything in the kit will probably prove useful, and some may even make a big difference.

Also useful is the paracord itself. It is not designed for climbing and supporting your weight, but will definitely allow you to lash together a shelter. Ironically, the implements are inside the paracord pouch, so the ziplock style bag becomes storage for as many of those as you can cram. Frankly, I think that the cardboard box that this comes in should be retained for better storage (albeit not very waterproof.)

This is obviously a collection of last resort tools that belong in bug-out bags and emergency kits. If you maintain such a kit this is a good candidate for inclusion if you anticipate being off the grid.

title: Easy to assemble, but some bizarre design choices text: [[VIDEOID:64c8658b81382127e4a89d8e490ca985]] My kids love camping, so when we got this tent they were excited to try popping it up in our playroom first before we take it out. Before I go any further, I want to point out that to its' credit, this tent was easy enough for a couple of girls aged 9 and 11 to figure it out themselves.
That being said, I'm glad we did it at home first because I noticed at least one weird design flaw: The outer door cover is REALLY difficult to close from the inside. You see, like many tents, the doors are two layers: an outer rain flap and an inner bug-net window screen. bug net opens in the middle with a zipper, and the outer later opens on the sides (attached from the top, zipper around the perimeter).
This is odd because it seems like it is only designed to be closed from the outside like this! The zipper for the outer flap has an inside handle, but if the bug screen is closed, you can't reach it. I suppose you could open the bug screen all the way in order to get to the zipper, but it seems a whole lot easier to close and open both from the outside than the inside, which I wasn't expecting.
I'm not sure how I feel about that, I suppose it will still do the job out at a campsite, but it just feels poorly thought out.

title: Good for Household Cutting Needs text: I’m not an outdoorsman, but I admit that a good, sharp nice does come in handy for different household needs. The Coast Double Lock Folding Knife is a very good knife for these purposes. It works well for cutting rope, carpet, and other things that are not easy to slice with ordinary knives or scissors.

I did have some problems when I first received this knife; namely, learning how to open it and then close it back into its protective handle. With other knives, you just grab the blade and pull. That technique will not work here. I started to turn to the internet for an answer when I finally figured it out. You have to move a small, rolling piece and move another metal piece for opening/closing. It’s a little awkward, but I like that it takes effort because it is an added measure of safety. I don’t need to worry so much if one of my kids would happen to find the knife in its locked position because there is almost no way they would figure out how to open it.

As I said, I don’t venture into the outdoors very often, so I have no need for a genuine hunting knife. But this knife is useful for much more than that. Anytime I have a difficult cutting job, like say, with heavy cardboard or rope, this knife comes to my rescue. Scissors will work for these purposes, but they take too much effort and leave you with sore fingers. This Coast knife slices through these materials with ease.

Overall, I am happy with this knife and recommend it for household use. I cannot comment on its effectiveness in the field, but I would bet it would work well for outdoorsman, too. It’s sharp and handy and the double locking mechanism helps make it safer to use.

title: I am very disappointed in the quality of the material text: As a person who purchases fleece to make blankets, I know my material well. This fleece material is one of the cheapest that can be purchased. If you look closely at it when it arrives (I bought it online) it looks as though its slightly clumpy or matted from the start. This means that after 4-6 washes this fleece material will definitely have a matted appearance and appear much more worn than it is. The fleece fabric used is also very thin. If you turn the jacket inside out and push your finger firmly into the fabric, it appears that it wouldn't take much pressure to tear. I'm not suggesting gauging it with a blunt object, but it should withstand normal pushing as a clothing item will get when be put on and taken off etc. Again., thats a test us fleece blanket makers check for when purchasing fabric for a blanket that we desire to last through years of "normal" wear and washing. I honestly do not feel this jacket would hod up well beyond maybe 6 months.
Columbia is known for having quality merchandise so that is why I chose this maker. I am very disappointed in the quality of the material. I am certain the reviews on here are from buyers who received their jacket, see how soft it is, tried it on and thought it was well made and left a glowing review. I am curious to hear an update from a buyer after they have worn and washed this jacket a few times. I bought this jacket on sale for $36.00 (original price tag of $60.00) Unfortunately I am returning it today.
Old Navy is known for using VERY cheap material for a majority of their clothing, however they use much better quality fleece for their jackets. I know because I own a couple Old Navy fleece jackets. they're not as stylish as Columbia. Quite plain actually, but mine have held up for several years and still look nice. Old Navy fleece jackets go on sale for $9.99 - $14.99 often, especially around Christmas. Looks like I'll be heading back there to pick a few more up.

title: Trust the brand- total quality!! text: After a failed attempt at an off brand set of ankle weights.. I felt it best to trust the “big guns” when it comes to athletics and sports equipment.. Ha! Adidas didn’t disappoint- they know what they’re doing and have perfected the art.. Duh!! (Shame on me for doubting there would be a difference!)

Compared to others- these weights are leaps and bounds more compatible to the human body.. they are not just a ring of weights with a buckle, end of story! This set has been put to the test in its design and the cut.. Wow! This actually contours with the ankle or wrist- personally, I find it best fits the ankle! But, can definitely be used on either. Using a soft material this shows attention to detail in the cut.. NO sharp edges or corners to irritate the skin. Believe me- this makes all the difference. (with my cheaper set I had cotton stuffed in my sock to combat sharp edging.. which failed me btw and was so not practical!!)

The interior sand or gel(?) used to create the weight is evenly disbursed which also is a necessity. Placement depends on muscles strengthen appropriately- and this does it’s job in spades. Note: if unsure which size weight to order.. keep in mind user activity and length of time! Trust me, even 2-3lb. seem light.. right up until 10min. into a run, workout, or even a walk- and you will feel it adding a difference! I chose 3lb. and find it compatible for those at an intermediate workout level.

Definitely recommend and admit its worth the extra investment to purchase a set from a trusted athletic company- you won’t be disappointed! Hoping this info can help your decision.. stay safe.

title: Works well but needs patience to set up correctly text: - Took me about 45 min to get it setup. You need lots of patience. Easier to install if bike on trainer so pedals and rear wheel move freely.
- you need to tell the computer the circumference of your tires. My tire size 700x45 was not listed on the chart in the instructions. It was listed on the chart on the cateye website - 2242.
- No tools except scissors to cut ends of zip ties (after everything is lined up and working). I also used black electrical tape to hold sensors in place while lining everything up.
-Important tip: Don’t tighten any zip ties until you are sure everything is lined up and working.
- It seems to be functioning correctly. Not sure if its accurate?? Wont be able to tell until I ride outside and compare it to my mapmyride app. Its one of the only computers I found that works with a trainer and is relatively inexpensive. $47.
To install:
- You need to put a magnet on a wheel spoke on back wheel and then attach a sensor to the bike chain stay. They have to be < 3 mm apart.
- You then need to put a magnet on the crank arm thats attached to the pedal and a sensor on the bike chain stay thats < 3 mm apart. You have to use a zip tie to attach the magnet. My pedal crank arm has an indentation in it, so i had to tape the zip tie to the bar so it doesn't slide around.
- You then take the wire attached to both sensors and attach it to the bike from the pedal up to the handle bars. You need to make sure the wire is attached so when you move the handle bars to turn the wheel, the wire is long enough and it doesn't tear or get caught.
- they included 10 zip ties. I used 9 of them. You need lots of patience to get it setup correctly. The magnets have to be lined up exactly with the sensors. There is a line on each sensor showing you where to line up the magnets. Its near the ends of the sensors not the middle.
- I have numerous items on my handlebars already - phone holder, bell, reflector, a mount for a computer. I attached this device to the computer mount but this computer is very small so its not a great fit. I had to wrap the strap around the mount.
- if you snap the computer onto the holder at the end of the wire, you can unattach it, but its very hard to do. Beware. You need to pull up on front of the computer while pushing back on it. I was afraid I was breaking it or would tear the wire away from the holder. I have done it several times to test it, and it’s still working.
I’m giving this a 4 star review pending longer term use. If it turns out to be accurate and lasts, I will bump it up to a 5 star.

title: Amazing! text: This bag comes exactly as advertised! I've been using it for several months now and so far hasn't developed any tears or holes. I have not been gentle with it. It holds all the gear I need for my shift. I left this thing out in the rain for a good 40 minutes and everything inside was dry with the exception of some droplets. The zipper was pretty stiff to begin with, however now that I've had a chance to break it in it works fine. Definitely reccomend this bag.

Update: used this thing in the oilfields in ND for 2 years and it managed to keep up with me the whole time. Left it out in -40°C weather as well as 110°C. It got covered in all kinds of chemicals (hydrochloric acid being one of them) and oil and grease and it still wouldn't give up. I regretfully got rid of it when I got laid off as it's time had come. After two years it only had 2 small holes from ware and the zipper no longer worked.

I cannot recommend this bag enough, I am still surprised at how durable this thing is. I really, really punished this bag and it kept going till the end.

title: Not worth it - you can get a pedometer on your phone for free. text: The sole purpose of buying this thing was to track my steps and sleep in hopes of losing weight as I decided to get serious about my workouts. I know people who've had these things and loved them. That's not me. I had a hard time getting the charger to stay in the band so it wouldn't always charge completely. It never tracked my sleep-NOT ONCE, it didn't accurately track my steps or the number of flights of stairs even when I was running stairs daily and worked with someone to ensure I was using this stupid thing properly. Within 2 weeks of having the fitbit, I was working out and sweating because that's what you do when you work out and the connector in the back got some sweat on it, the stupid thing stopped working completely. Guess how much it is to fix it?!? That's right, the price of a new one.

Needless to say, I've given up and just decided to be fat. To hell with it.

title: I wish this was a better light text: Such a disappointing purchase. I guess I can blame this on my unwillingness to spend more time researching bicycle gear, it's just that with this and that and all the other little time sucking tasks I have, I figured buying a light for my bike shouldn't take more than a minute.

But this light really blows.

First off, it doesn't put off enough light, I could strap a jar full of glow worms to my handlebar and it would light my way much better.

Second the 'torch' rattles more than a shocks free volvo on a bumpy road. I think a liberal wrapping of duct tape would help with this, but then how would you replace the batteries? Speaking of batteries . . .

This is a battery hog. Maybe all that rattling did something to the batteries, but I barely made it to the second to last turn on my way home before the wispy glow of the torch winked out. This was after replacing the batteries with shiny new coppertops, sigh, what a disappointment.

Last but not least, I bought two! I hate it when I waste money.

title: Not auto-dimming. You’re also not putting this on your dog’s collar.

title: Good Backup or for practice only, Not For EDC text: This is a great SOCP knife for the price. The sheath is even better then the knife. You can see the knife is cheaply made and can get caught while removing from the sheath. This is a great defensive or last ditch weapon. Although I wouldn't want to rely on it to save my life. I prefer my Ka-Bar TDI LE duty knife https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0017V1I70/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o03_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1&pldnSite=1

However for the price this is an excellent knife. It is not that easy to resharpen unless you are familiar with the process. It's too light for my taste. It's a little awkward to really grip it like you would if your in a knife fight. It gets snagged while trying to slide into molle kit.

Anyone who says they would rely on this knife and it's good for military purposes is either paid or has no idea what they are talking about because it will not! This is a great practice or throw away knife. It has it's uses and for the price you can't go wrong. With a little more effort this could be a great knife. I was able to sharpen it on both sides while adding a nice tip. It's throws decently now. Won't last very long though.

title: Really nice rack text: The rack is solid. Really easy to attach to the hitch. In our case I have to problem whatsoever to attach it when we need it and remove it right after use using the included hardware. One review mentioned that leaves it exposed to a theft, so I tossed a wrench and remove the rack while we are biking (it takes about a minute). Perhaps the greatest feature are those bike cradles and straps. We transport 3 bikes - 1 men frame, 1 women and 1 children's. They all hang at different angles, but all 3 are very solid and unmovable. The collapsible frame is a nice feature too. Once I forgot to close the door while I already had one bike attached to the rack (yeah, I was tired after a long ride :-)) Lowered the rack with that bike on it, closed the door, return the rack back to upright position and kept loading the remaining 2 bikes.

The only (perceived maybe) con of this rack - it is a bit wobbly when it is loaded and the car is moving. When I keep that in mind and drive a bit more carefully that does not appear to be an issue. Note that bikes are attached securely and do not move at all even a little bit relative to each other or to the frame. But the entire thing wobbles slightly left and right when the car moves on an uneven pavement. I do not think this is a hitch connector issue as it fits snugly into a hitch receiver. Could be that the 1.25" to 2" adapter just cannot provide enough support. Or maybe that's the inherent weakness of hitch-mounted racks (the connection to the receiver cannot be rigid enough). Or both... Take into account that this is our first rack and I have no experience whatsoever with other racks. They probably all wobble, I just do not have a good reference to say whether this wobbles more or less.

title: Not just for drinking, but a perfect bottle to refill humidifiers... text: THE GOOD:
---------------
* 128 oz. = 1 gallon.
* Aesthetically, a really nice looking bottle with a nice color scheme.
* Smooth finished product. Cheap plastic products sometimes have sharp plastic edges that didn't get completely cut off during production. You ever felt a prick in your fingers when handling a milk bottle by the handle? No such things to worry about here. This is high quality, not dollar store quality.
* Two openings at the top. One is for drinking, the other is a bigger hole for chugging.
* BPA free.

THE BAD:
------------
* Nothing at all.

I had reviewed a very similar bottle. I thought there would be a chance that this would be the same bottle, fortunately it is not, and this one actually exactly what I need. I'm not getting this for working out or hiking, I simple need a gallon bottle to pour into humidifiers. I've been using the supermarket gallon bottles as is. I wanted something where I no longer have to uncap and recap. The other similar bottle I reviewed only had one sippy opening, so pouring was slow. This one has 2 openings, and the "chug" opening is perfect for pouring out quickly. Easy push of button to expose the chug opening. I no longer need to uncap and recap. Exactly what I needed.

5-Stars.

title: Definitely best for older toddler 3+ yr old.. text: Solid balance bike- one that feels sturdy and brings confidence in its overall structure.. light blue has a retro feel. Bike has easy construction and one just needs to attach the seat with included tool and you’re ready to go! Note: Seat can be adjusted up or down.. photos included show seat at its lowest level- still a bit too high for our 31 mo. old..

I also compared photos of the balance bike sized just below this bike.. and you can see it is a large jump up in size! Wish there was a size in between.. bike is light and easy to control, its one a toddler can hold up under his own merit. Solid tires compiled of materials vs. air means no flat tire to worry about. Spongy neoprene handles help grip- but the issue comes in the ability to touch the ground!! Leg length is too short- this is from a toddler in the 53% for height and weight so, I expect it to be the same results for others as well…

*while learning to balance- bike can be used indoors.. if it hasn’t gone outside to dirty tires first. Something I’d suggest mastering prior to outdoor concrete!

The only structural issue or change id prefer to see- is the foot pegs to rest feet on be a bit bigger. With a toddlers dexterity it’s hard for them to balance feet on the tiny 1x1” platforms. The feet struggle to find the spot and stay put.. I am hoping as he ages up this will fix itself.

title: Handy and a bargain, but read the limitations before making a final decision text: I received these as a free review sample. They are excellent for shelter, porch or patio lighting, or even as a path finding light. They are not a good substitute for a torch-style light because the LEDs are bright and cover 360 degrees, making them inconvenient for close in repair work at night. That is not an issue or flaw, but I need to mention it because it's surprising how many folks have never used a lantern-type light and how disappointed they are to discover some of that style's limitations.

In a tent these are bright enough to illuminate a lot of area, but not especially bright for reading. That depends on your eyes. At 67 I need a strong light and this is not sufficient, but for a younger person this will probably work for reading.

There are only two modes: On and Off. Pull up and they immediately illuminate. The three batteries that ship with each unit are non-rechargeable, so the eight or so hours I got from them make them expensive for anything more than overnight camping unless you invest in a good set of rechargeable batteries and a solar charger like this one: [[ASIN:B000XD9O2E Solar 2 in 1 Folding Panel, Power supply, AA and AAA battery charger.]]

Also be aware of the fact that while this is fairly impervious to inclement weather there are some limitations. Foremost is it has to be off the ground because the screw off cover for the battery compartment is not completely water proof. Hanging from a branch or raised above the water level, though, will allow it to operate without issues. If you absolutely need to use this in a wetter environment you can fashion a gasket or O-ring from neoprene that would seal the compartment. Again, not a design flaw (especially at the list price), but something of which you should be aware.

Bottom line: for me these are handy. I have one in my vehicle for emergencies, and another in my enclosed patio. They are not a light I would use all the time because of battery consumption, but are very convenient (and effective) when I need to illuminate an area quickly.

When you see that you are doing well or better you can cheer yourself. I think something like this can make all the difference in achieving your goals. I would recommend it.

title: Great Glove For Beginners Works Great - Our Daughter Loves It text: My daughter is a new baseball player. She really wanted a glove that she could use that was her own and not borrowed. Although she did not play a fielding position a whole lot, she still found it useful. I was more of a real leather fan of gloves, but this one is a nice glove, especially for anyone starting out in baseball.

WHAT IS THIS GLOVE LIKE?
This glove is not genuine leather. It is soft grippy faux leather that has a nice curvy fit to it. The inside has a thumb loop in it which helps to control the glove when using it. The pocket is soft, yet tough and woven stripes of faux leather that is black in color. The inside has faux fur strip on the back of the hand, and the inside is slick enough to allow the glove to be put on and taken off quickly without being too slick. There is an adjustable tab to help tighten the thumb area, if necessary.

HOW DID THIS GLOVE PERFORM?
My daughter is thrilled with this glove. She said that even when she was playing catcher it was a great glove. She had good control, was able to grab the ball with ease and accuracy. She loves the thumb loop inside.

CON
More velcro to adjust the thumb loop would be nice

WHAT SIZE HAND?
My daughter has a medium size ladies hand with shorter fingers than most women. I have a medium to large sized hand with longer fingers. This glove fits both of our hands nicely. Our son has a medium to large man's hand and it does not fit his hand. I would say that this is for a small man's hand, larger youth hand, or a medium to large women's size hand.

THE BOTTOM LINE
Although she wishes that the adjustment for the thumb was a bit longer velcro, this glove has been a wonderful glove for our daughter as she begins to play baseball. It fits very well, is comfortable for longer periods of time, yet comes off easily if necessary. It worked well for all of her positions played including catcher. This glove remained pliable and worked very well allowing for accuracy and gripping action.

FIVE stars for this glove. It is a hit in this family (for those who can wear it)

title: Granddaughters love it
text: My granduaghters (3,7) both love LOL dolls so they were excited when this arrived. Instructions were easy to follow. Parts all came in good condition with no dents, scrapes or missing parts. Putting on the springs weren't as hard as I imagined. The last small screws that went in were the hardest and took a lot of elbow grease. Some of the very top horizontal curved bars face more inward than others so it was hard to tell which way they went. Could use a label since you can't tell until you have them up if they are the right direction. Overall I liked almost  everything about this, except the last part of tying the elastic straps on. There are A LOT of them and wasn't sure if I should be double knotting or single knotting them. Wish there was a better way to secure it than individually knotting all the straps. I was able to do almost all of the assembly by myself, but used some help when putting on the net. But I think one person could do it all just fine. Took about an hour and half to assemble. This is a good size if you have a small yard. Both granddaughters fit on it just fine even though it says one person only. It has good bounce to it as well. For the price, I would probably buy the 7ft little tikes trampoline without the LOL graphics or 7ft Best Choice trampoline. They are both almost $100 less expensive.

title: Tough case with vibrant color, good latches, automatic seal & easy to manage foam text: The color is vibrant, the latches work well & the handle is handy but not rubberized. The case seals up well & the casing seems tough but I haven't tested for durability or waterproofing. The pull & pluck foam is easy to work with. The little squares are around 5/8" & separate a lot cleaner if they are trimmed with a blade first. I was concerned about the non-separated pieces around the edges but they are holding up well.
The case is smaller than I expected. With all of the reinforcements & thick seal on the outside, there is a diminishing return of space on the inside with smaller sizes. The dimensions in the description are quite accurate. I have a holstered G26 in my pictures & it turned out to be tight. A 1911 might fit but would be happier in a larger case.
I have Pelican cases & the ones from the tool store. The thing that this case & Pelicans have is a valve that lets you check it on an airplane without it inflating like a balloon but still being waterproof. I was inspecting the valve on this one as soon as I got it & managed to break the cover off of the valve.

title: Fine Tea Bottle text: [[VIDEOID:fdb4235f3eadd013641a9a7f0b748853]] I sometimes will treat myself to hot tea in the afternoons when I am working in the office. I like tea bottles over cups as I am a lot less likely to spill tea in a bottle versus a cup, so I have several that I keep on my desk. I was interested in trying this tea bottle, and it has worked out well for me so far.

One thing that is different about this bottle is the screen. The screen is located at the bottom of the bottle, not at the top. It also is bigger than most, being slightly larger than a 35mm film tube. The holes in it are small enough to keep larger particles form getting the tea but they are not small enough to keep something like fine tea leaves (or regular ground coffee) out.

The bottle is borosilicate glass and is single layer. So, to compensate for the lack of insulation the bottle comes with a sleeve that keeps you from burning your hand and also helps to keep the contents of the bottle hot (or cold, as appropriate). The sleeve is easy to put on and take off.

The bottle comes with two bottle brushes and a handle for those brushes. The brushes are simply foam heads on a plastic handle but they are sufficient for properly cleaning out the bottle.

So far this bottle has worked out well for me. I am happy with it.

Disclosure: I was provided a sample of this product in exchange for a fair, honest and thorough review. Even though I received this product at minimal or no cost I have rated and reviewed this product without bias, based solely on my experience with it.

text: I was very surprised by this knife for the better.  I usually go by the philosophy that you get what you pay for when purchasing firearms, knives, daggers or any weapon in general. Normally I don't like any design or added stuff on my knives but the design is really good looking.  I could do without the silver shiny skulls personally  but it your hold it  correctly it's covered any way.  The blade was extremely shard out of the box and that's not always the case, especially with lower cost knives.  The assisted opening has a bit too much resistance for me but it still very good.  I like the stainless steel blade and it can be thrown if you know what you are doing.  It's not center balanced or designed for throwing, but with a little practice or instruction you can learn to throw almost any knife.  I really didn't think I was going to like this purchase and was going to give it as a gift, but decided to add it to my collection instead.

title: They Laughed At Me When I Got This, BUT.. text: When I first got this, it was with the intention that in the dead of winter, I would have a way to exercise gently and get my body to be in shape somewhat. My family laughed at me. They are not laughing now.

WHAT IS THIS LIKE?
This came in a box with all of the legs tied back to the trampoline with elastic cords. Each leg is shock corded with metal shock cords, much like you find in a tent. That means that when you want to put it away, you won't be losing any legs.

HANDLE
The handle that comes with it is optional. You can use the trampoline with or without it. It is not hard to put together and it is good if you are hard with balance and need some stabilizing when first using the trampoline.

SPRINGS
The springs of this are very sturdy and well made. I was surprised at how nice they were. They easily held up to 250 lbs of everyone who tried it.

SURFACE
The surface is easy to use barefoot or with shoes on.

EDGES
The edges are protected so that if you wander in your bouncing that you won't hit the edges and plow through the springs as easily.

DOES IT HELP?
I have to say that despite the silliness of the sound, if you just gently bounce on this, it does take a lot out of you and it really does help keep in shape. I intend to use this regularly this winter.

PROBLEMS?
I had only one problem. When I put the legs into place, it is very hard to get them out once it has been used. I think I will put silicone spray on it or something in the future. I want to fold it flat, using the elastic ties that it comes with for easier storage when not in use.

THE BOTTOM LINE
A great exercise unit, this is sturdy, well made, and easy to use. It does fold flat for easier storage, but the frame is stable and strong.

MY RATING
I like this. It really works, feels good to use, and once I get the leg thing worked out, I am sure I will be loving this all winter.

title: Will not fit my 2006 Toyota Camry Solara Convertible; also does not fit my boyfriend's 2010 Honda Accord w/o a special part text: I did not realize that this would not fit my car. I have a 2006 Toyota Camry Solara Convertible and the box says it will not fit years 1993 to 2008. Nevertheless, I decided to see for myself. Due to the way the bike rack is configured, the top bar almost comes off the trunk. As a result, there would be room for only one bike as the track adjusts back and forth depending on how tight it has to be cinched (based on the car model, of course). There are two provided clips that go through the holes to keep the track from sliding after the correct length is reached.

I then wanted to try this on my boyfriend's car which is a 2010 Honda Accord and it also will not fit that either without a special part. Overall, I am disappointed. I had automatically assumed bike racks were universal and did not realize that was not the case. I also did not realize that there is a chart that can be consulted to check for fit. That was my mistake.

Despite this, based on what I have noticed with this rack, the instructions are not very good. Both my boyfriend and I tried to figure them out and found them confusing. In addition, neither one of us believe this would fit three bikes unless the top rod was fastened all the way out and I doubt one would have that option on every car. Had this worked on my car, I would have given this three stars based on my other observations.

title: Decent lock, seems comparable to other brands text: While I bought this lock to try and keep my new e-bike mine. The lock itself looks like it will do the job, but be aware. This lock is a bit short for my exact e-bike (Lextric XP step thru 2.0). It might be hard for it to go through anything more than the frame and possibly lock on a structure that thieves can't move. Most likely I will have to use this lock in combination with other locks to get enough length to secure all the wheels and still reach a structure to keep the bike from being dragged away. The included cable is nice to be included. Just not sure how well it would survive a cut attack.

While D-Lock style locks seem to be the best to stop average thieves. Until a real pro thief tries to steal your bike. Its hard to say how well this lock will do. It looks like this Sigtuna lock and the 2 other locks I have should do the trick to keep my bike mine.

I will also mention that a regular tube style frame is fine for the lock holders for the D-Lock and cable. They might be a challenge to use on an E-Bike that has a frame with internal battery and few tube areas to mount to.

I'll update my review should anything happen. BTW I bought this lock based on others reviews and price. So far, the reviews feel about accurate.

title: Dressy, Never Needs Charging, But Doesn't Track Much text: This KATE SPADE NY BLACK SCALLOP ACTIVITY TRACKER is dressy, and never needs charging (because it's powered by a coin battery), but it's definitely an "activity tracker lite". All it does for "activity" is track steps, calories (as computed by an algorithm), distance, and a few goals (e.g., sleep, daily water glasses). It also has a countdown to important events (birthdays, etc.) feature that gives notifications.

The Quick Start guide is unhelpful. It tells you to download the companion app to your smartphone, and has diagrams for inserting the supplied battery in the watch. The downloaded app tells you how to register for an online account that will actually keep track of your data. The reviews of the app in the Google Play store report that the app is flaky, and may wipe your data.

The watchband is cheap, made of rubber (though it doesn't actually look cheap). This "activity tracker" is basically a toy. I'm sticking with my [[ASIN:B00N2BW2PK Fitbit Charge HR]], which isn't pretty or dressy, but is a serious activity tracker that does much, much more, including telling the time and date.

title: O'Neill HEAT 4/3mm LFS vs O'neill EPIC 4/3mm GBS vs Hyperflex Voodoo 4/3mm LFS vs Quiksilver Syncro 5/4/3mm LFS!!! text: At 62 I have been a lifelong big wave surfer and a very strong long distance swimmer (2-3 miles per day 4-5 days/week). I am 5' 11'' tall, with a 31'' inseam, 38-40" waist, 46-47" chest, 52" around my shoulders, and 34" arms with only 13.5" biceps. I gained a lot of weight last year so 3 months ago I hooked up a harness in my pool and lost 20 lbs. swimming 1-3 miles per day in a NeoSport XSpan 3/2mm 2XXL full wetsuit. Now at 227 lbs I am aiming for about 205-210 lbs. by spring, but the water temp cooled to 68 degrees and the 3/2mm wetsuit was no longer sufficiently warm. Water was flushing in my neck and back quite a bit. I first layered a 1.5mm neoprene shirt under my 3/2mm wetsuit and got more warmth and less flushing, but arm flexibility was compromised.
I decided to test the following 3 backzip wetsuits, and I really hoped the Hyperflex Voodoo would be my best choice for swimming in waters that might hit around 45 degrees;

1. Hyperflex Voodoo 4/3mm XXL (LFS)
2. O'Neill Epic 4/3mm XXL (GBS)
3. O'Neill HEAT 4/3mm XXL (LFS)
4. Quiksilver Syncro 5/4/3mm XXL (LFS)

1. Hyperflex Voodoo 4/3mm XXL (LFS) My first shock was that the Voodoo was the hardest suit to put on by far (even over a thin lycra bodysuit) partly because of the non-slip fleece lining, but also because the arms were very tight on my skinny arms, and the suit was extremely tight around my shoulders. I had to have help pulling the floodgate over my head, and zipping the suit up. I am surprised I did not feel terribly choked by the floodgate or by the wetsuit neck when zipped up. Even though the tightness in the shoulders was stretching the neck piece a little, the neck piece still remained comfortably snug. Over all I felt like I was in a 5mm standard 50% flex neoprene wetsuit rather than a 100% stretch suit. This XXL was terribly restrictive of my shoulders and arms, and it felt like I feared a XXL-Short wetsuit might feel. I knew I'd be warm in this suit even in 45-50 degree water, and I'd have very little if any water flushing, but I could not imagine swimming 1/2 mile in this suit even after wearing it for over an hour indoors because if the lack of flexibility in the arms and shoulders.

2. O'Neill Epic 4/3 mm XXL (GBS)
AND
3. O'Neill HEAT 4/3mm XXL-short (LFS)

The 2 O'neill suits both went on extremely easily, which shocked me, and both fit me absolutely perfectly even thought the HEAT was a 2XL-Short and the Epic just an XXL. I purposely didn't stretch the Epic 4/3mm out when I put it on though it would have stretched out a bit in length in the legs if I needed it to. The HEAT fit me perfectly EVERYWHERE. The Neoprene in both suits was absolutely buttery, and both felt far more flexible than the Voodoo 4/3mm or than a NeoSport Xspan 5mm had felt a month earlier. The heat retention of the front panel in both suits was immediately evident. The Liquid Fluid Seal over all the seams on the HEAT 4/3mm suit were totally stretchy, and the added back heat panels convinced me I would be significantly warmer in the Heat 4/3mm than in the Epic 4/3mm suit with GBS seams. My only initial complaint with both O'neill suits was that the shape of the neck put a little pressure on the front of my throat - perhaps because my posture is not great and I stand with my head tilted forward a little (genetic trait) - but this issue became completely unnoticeable once I took the Heat 4/3mm and then the Epic 4/3mm into the water.

4. Quiksilver Syncro 5/4/3mm XXL (LFS) - For a cold water suit, this would have been my second choice behind the O'neill HEAT with LFS. It went on easily even with the back floodgate, and I was able to zip it up without help from my wife. The Neoprene felt absolutely wonderful and stretchy, the seams were Liquid-Fluid Sealed and not just GBS seams, and the suit felt totally comfortable once zipped up. My arms and shoulders had easy and full range of motion and I knew I could swim miles warmly in this suit. My only issue and reason for spending $70 more on the O'neill HEAT was that the QuikSilver Syncro 2XL was at least 3 inches too long for me in the legs because I have shorter legs and a longer torso. The arms were also a little long for me, bulging a little around my biceps, but fitting snugly and sealing well at my wrists and all the way up my forearms. If I lose the 20 lbs. the O'neill HEAT XXLS will still fit me well, but the Quiksilver Syncro XXL would then become way too loose.

My wife watched me try on and compare each suit, and since the O'neill HEAT 4/3mm obviously fit me the best and had the features I needed to swim long distances in cold water, after trying on the other suits I immediately made my decision and kept the O'neill HEAT 4/3mm suit on. I threw on some 5mm NeoSport booties, donned a swim cap and 3mm Neosport gloves, stepped down into a pool of 58 degree water (not feeling the slightest chill), hooked myself into the swimming harness and immediately went face first into the water to swim a mile. Only my cheeks were a little chilled at first. I felt NO water getting in through the neck, or the seams of my O'neill HEAT wetsuit. I felt No Chill at all !!! In fact, after about a quarter mile I pulled down on the front collar to let in a little water in to cool me down in the suit.

After loving the O'Neill Heat, and looking at the recommended water temperature range of 45 degrees and up, I decided to try the O'Neill Epic 4/3mm GBS in the water. I jumped into the 58 degree water and felt a little more cooling water seeping in than with the HEAT, but I was warmed up from the mile swim so I decided to swim another 1/2 mile. I decided to keep the O'neill Heat 4/3mm for cold waters 45 degrees and up, the O'neill Epic 4/3mm for 56-57 degrees and up, and my Neosport XSpan 3/2mm would for waters 68 degrees and up.

I hope this free personal testimony about these wetsuits helps you make your next decision about the wetsuit that is right for you.

title: 4 Stars For This Senior Citizen But 5 Stars For Most People text: The photo above was taken in the evening about an hour and a half before sunset. The lantern has four settings - low, medium, high, and flashing and in the photo it is set on medium. You can see how bright that is. In the dark, the low setting is about on a par with most regular flashlights. The high setting lights up a dark room. The lantern is lightweight, making it very portable, but it doesn't feel at all flimsy. Instead, the unit has a sturdy heft to it.

One of the nicest features of this lantern is the Battery Guard which prevents the batteries from slowly draining away over time. Maybe once every 12-18 months we'll lose power in my area for an extended period. I got this lantern as emergency lighting in such situations so I don't end up sitting in the dark until the power company gets the problem resolved. That means my lantern will be sitting on the shelf for upwards of a year or more between uses. You can see why I like that Battery Guard function so much.

Why the four star/five star distinction in the title? As a 70 year old guy with some health issues it's getting harder and harder for me to do a lot of physical things. Getting the batteries into the lantern caused a bit of a hassle for me, things which more able-bodied folks probably wouldn't even notice. First, of the four D batteries it needs, two need to go in one direction and two in the other. If I hadn't noticed at the last second where the + and - signs were, I'd have put them in wrong. That would only have been an issue because getting the cover back into place over the batteries was a bit of an effort for me. I had to brace the lantern upside down on a countertop and press hard to get that cover far enough down for me to screw it back on. That was my own weak muscles though. Most people would be able to put the batteries in without any problems at all, which is why I am giving this a full fiver star rating. I think it's an excellent product.

title: Worked Well for Summer Visiting text: We had some company for the summer for a few weeks. Having access to a small grill was important for the young adults.

LIGHTWEIGHT
This is not paper weight by any means, but it is light weight enough that it is easy to move and relocate.

DOES IT SIT FIRMLY?
This has to have a stand, stable surface or a table top to use it. It is pretty sturdy.

USE
This is electronic ignition and the center burner has to be lit with a lighter. Be sure to have one handy if you plan to use it.

They did not have any issues with operating the burners. They are big enough to put a decent pan on. A simple cast iron skillet (8-10 inches) fit well on the burner.

GRILL
The grill was not overly impressive to anyone. It is okay for a quick piece of toast, but otherwise, they were not that thrilled with it.

QUALITY OF BUILD
This seems well made and sturdy.

THE BOTTOM LINE
This grill is sturdy, the burners performed well, and it seems to be well made. The grill was not that thrilling and no one wanted to use it much.

MY RATING
FIVE STARS. As a basic stove, it worked great on a 1 lb tank of propane (which my husband bought by accident last year instead of butane). The grill was not why we got it, so not using it much is not that big of a deal.

title: PERFECT For What I Wanted It For text: I have a situation where at any time, I might have to move in with someone in the family who is having health issues. the problem is that they have a bed that is almost impossible for me to sleep on. It is softer than the floor, but not by much. I have wanted a mat to bring with me in the car in case I had to use it on a sudden overnight. I also wanted something I could quickly inflate to put in the deck if I wanted to lay out. Let's take a look.

WHAT IS THIS LIKE?
This comes in a nice pouch. It closes nicely and has a lock on it. Inside are inflating instructions. There is also a patch inside which is nice too if you need to patch up the mattress.

HOW DOES IT WORK?
This is so fascinating. In the bag, it does not take up much room. I would put it equivalent to rolling up a queen sized top sheet by folding in fourths and rolling it up. Maybe a tiny thicker than that.

You unscrew the cap once it is open and suddenly the air starts to fill the mattress. If you are in a hurry, you can blow in it unless it is cold out then it is not recommended. Once you have it where you want it, then you can screw it back closed and lay on it.

HOW DOES IT FEEL?
This is surprisingly comfortable. I had it on my very hard wood deck and was amazingly comfortable laying on my back- something that is not what I can normally do without a mattress. It is not super thick, but the foam and air combo make for a nice supportive experience taking the edge off of the hardness of the deck.

HOW HARD IS IT TO PUT AWAY?
Putting away was very fast too. I just opened the cap, and gently rolled bottom up and then re-rolled again to get all of the air out. It takes some practice, but it was put away in just a few minutes. It actually fits in the bag without having to struggle a lot like some products of this nature.

HOW LONG IS THIS?
This is quite long. I would say that this would take someone up to 6ft tall at least easily. The foot area is not too big, but it is nice.

DOES IT SQUEAK?
There was not any noise when using this. It also did not slide all over the place, another thing I can not stand.

CAMPING
If you take this camping, I would make sure it has a double tarp under it or a tarp and tent floor at least. You want to protect this from rocks and sharp objects as it can tear, despite being pretty tough.

THE BOTTOM LINE
This is not only fabulously bright and cheerful, but it is ingenious. The foam air combo is perfect for me. It works on the deck and also on a very hard mattress. It is small enough to keep in the car or travel with and will fit in a tent nicely. It is fast to set up and take down too.

MY RATING
FIVE STARS. I love this mattress more than the others I have tried. It is the one that I am keeping in my car as my husband fell for another one I have so he can sleep in other locations from time to time when he has to.

title: Not exactly a blanket, but is highly useful for the beach or other things text: When I received this as a review sample I was surprised by how compact it was - it was folded in a bag that measured less than 12 inches by 10 inches and a little over an inch thick. It's definitely compact and easy to store.

The design is clever, but I am going to avoid repeating the product description or Comdet's detailed July 26, 2014 review. I actually took this to a stretch of beach in Daytona Beach Shores to test it out. The sand is fairly hard packed so the metal stakes were sufficient. If you intend to use this on a beach that is sandier you may want to use different stakes that will stay in the ground. The loops on the corners will fit just about any stake you can buy. Of course, if you want to increase your load, four paving stones, which fit into the sand pockets - plus the stakes - will probably keep this in place regardless of the breeze. That is the main issue with this or any other beach blanket because a little wind under this 7x6 foot blanket turns it into a large sail.

I love the material for keeping sand off things. It's thin, super thin,in fact, so it's more of a sand barrier that you can lay on as long as you find a comfortable spot on the beach. Note that this is purposely not waterproof, so it cannot be used as a tarp in a rain. On the other hand, it will dry very quickly and it your beach spot has a wash station you can rinse this to remove all sand, and it will dry in literally minutes.

Now that I have tested it for what it was designed to do my use is as a dust cover for my drum kit. I have two set up in my studio and they collect dust (even if I play them every day), so this will be going over the one I use least. The cool thing is this 'blanket' will function for a number of purposes between visits to the beach. It's light, can be secured to corners and will even block the sun on that south side window. Let your imagination run amok.

title: Good quality lantern! text: This is quite a handy lantern! It is easy to work, meaning you have three light beams. There is a lower, slightly higher and of course the strobe, which is great for signaling. It does take 3 C batteries. A handle is convenient for carrying. The lantern has a solid, quality feel to it. Also, the lantern has a faint light blinking that is constant, and it blinks every few seconds. This is so you can find it when needed. Again, it is faint.

The difference between the regular light and the higher beam is not much at all.

Great for camping, light for the tent, and excellent for late night walks or hikes. Use it around the yard, patio, etc.

Again, this is a quality lantern, bright LED light.... Review for product. ...... Rizzo

title: Weapon of Bass Destruction text: I love to go freshwater fishing and this weekend I approached the lake with a brand new weapon - a KastKing Sharky 6000 spinning reel. This is a serious reel that made a good day of fishing even better.

I will start by saying that even though it is approximately the same weight as my primary reel - a KastKing Orcas 4000 - it is significantly larger. I spooled on over 200 yards of 10-lb. test fluorocarbon line and it still had room for more line on it. I put it on an 8' limber rod and headed out to a productive spot.

I am very fussy about my reels and I expect them to meet several criteria. I want a good cast range, a smooth cast, smooth retrieve, quiet operation and a zero-reverse clutch. There has to be enough clearance between my knuckles and the bail to keep it from rapping me on the knuckles when I retrieve. And finally, the drag has to work and be easy to set. The Sharky met every one of these requirements.

I learned fast (and the hard way) that the reel is more than accommodating when it comes to casting and more than once I sent my lures into the trees instead of to the edge of the bank when I was unable to hit the bank with other reels on identical rods. This required a little adjustment on my part but it meant I did not have to work as hard and it also meant I could hit farther targets when I wanted to. So, when I fish from the bank I have a better range into whatever water I am fishing.

The retrieve is glassy smooth and very fast too. Not once did I have a problem with snarled line on the retrieve when I had near-zero load which is a problem on some reels. I like that I could bring in the line very quickly when needed (like for grabbing the net to assist another fisherman). The reel is quiet when spinning - not silent, but quiet.

When the ant-reverse clutch is engaged there is no reverse at all. To me this is a sign that the reel is quality made and is assembled well. I really, really dislike reels that do not have a zero-reverse clutch, and even worse is a reel that has one but it still has just a little play in it. The Sharky’s zero-reverse is solid and works exactly like it’s supposed to work - absolutely zero reverse.

The bail spins an inch or so away from my knuckles but never once has it hit my hand when spinning.

The drag set is uniform and smooth and does not really get harder to turn until close to the end of the tightening range.

In appearance this is a very attractive reel, black and red with a little bit of chrome. It is surprisingly lightweight for the size. I have bigger hands than average so a reel this size that doesn’t add much more weight is very welcome.

The reel helped me land a good variety of fish including largemouth bass, crappie and a near-citation yellow perch. The most exciting catch was a largemouth bass which was not huge but not small either and provided the best test of the reel under stress, and the reel brought this fish to the boat easily without incident. Even under the load of a fighting bass the reel was just as smooth in operation as when retrieving a test plug.

I am very, very pleased with the Sharky 6000 and will be using it again in the same lake in a few weeks. It has not let me down even once and it works very well. If you want a larger reel that works great and does not add a lot of weight to your gear, take a very close look at this reel.

Disclaimer: I was provided a sample of this product in exchange for a fair, honest and thorough review. Even though I received this product at no cost I have rated and reviewed this product without bias, based solely on my experience with it.

Doesn’t shrink if wash in cold water, and retains its compression well.  Definitely worth wearing after a long run.  I love compression for speedy recovery too.

It also is easy enough for my 9 y.o. to adjust himself. Because these adjust so generously, they will last until your child has about a size 3 shoe.

title: Sturdy tees in a nice container text: These tees are probably best for good golfers who are looking for every marginal gain they can find. I, however, am not a good golfer, and I don’t notice any difference with these tees versus regular plastic ones. In other words, they aren’t magic and they didn’t make make me a better player.

But the black coating on top of the tees makes my fingers feel more slick, so it does seem to reduce friction as advertised. Also, for the 3 1/4 in size, I got 12 tees in the cardboard tube. It seems expensive to me when regular tees work just as well.

Texture allows easy clean and rinse.  Drys very quickly.  You still need to roll it via short sides as I wasn’t comfortable enough to fold along the long side. title: Looks good but lots of issues
text: If you want a cheap iPhone watch this is a good option BUT… it has as very short battery life if you’re trying to check messages and read the time all the time. I turned off notifications and I turned off the function that flashes the watch face everytime you raise your arm. The batter will run for weeks like that. If you turn all the things on you’ll have to plug it in every 4-5 days. Not awful if that’s your jam but I wear it all the time to keep track of steps and sleep and it just runs and runs and runs. One thing I don’t like is the mesh metal band. It snags on everything, clothing, hair, bedding any fabric. The hair thing is especially annoying. I’d recommend the non mesh bands. But the look of the mesh is cool. Also the magnet closure is always coming lose. It slides around and just isn’t tight enough. I fiddle with it a lot. Needs a stronger magnet and it’s less than a month and already tarnishing. Last thing, step count is low but it’s good for motivation and don’t get too attached to the watch face. My watch cycled through watch faces at random. Not sure why.

We really like things to keep the kids active. I would much prefer them doing something than watching something. It is great because it is like a game for them but then they are being physically active.

The quality was good. It worked as it was supposed to. It wasn’t too hard to set up.

This is a great activity for a day when you don’t know what else to do or you want your child to burn off some energy. It is a good way to keep a child busy.

The children really liked it.

I feel like this is good for child development. It kept my children's interest. It would also make a nice gift.

I would recommend it.

title: Returned it for a Weber!!!!!
text: Order this item 2 weeks ago. Got it in the mail and took it out and one of the side table chrome playe fell of and the Paul Jr designs label was popping up. The lid was off centered so te lid was hard to close you really had to push i and down and line it up to latch. I was already annoyed at this point since it was a gift for my husband and I couldn't wait for him to see it. As heavy as it is te lid is really flimsy and I think needs heavy hinges and better latch. That's not all though... and took it camping right away 2 days later. My husband turned it on and the popping sound started and he opened it and black flakes flying everywhere. Stupid me didnt pack a campfire grill grate just in case and we ended up having to cover the grates in aluminium foil for our steaks and brats and use the camper microwave and futch oven for everything else! What a pain. We were super dissapointed. Should have got the original. 3 of our camping friends have te original and love it. We love our Weber Genesis at home so we did a return instead of a replacement and are going to get the Weber Q. I should have listened to the other negative reviews but thought Coleman would have fixed the issues by now- guess not!

title: Glass vs. ANY type of plastic? Glass wins! text: I am a big iced tea drinker yet began to stop drinking so much after finding the taste of my home brewed green tea lately not so good. I was using BPA-free plastic containers to make and store the tea in when I came across an article about using glass for a much purer taste.

I searched Amazon and came across these bottles. The price was right (cheaper than the manufacturer's website price) and the user ratings pretty good. Combining these bottles with a glass Pyrex measuring cup to make the tea I have noticed an immediate improved taste. I allow the tea to cool before pouring it into the bottles (I read if you place the tea in when it's hot the cap might seal so tightly you may have difficulty opening the bottle) and it tastes great now!

I use 3 bottles for tea and the other three for water (which also tastes much better vs. BPA-free plastic). I am planning to get a small fridge for another room and will buy another case of these bottles to store tea and water in.

title: Great
text: Great! Works as advertised.

title: Excellent backpack, rides nicely without sticking, comfortable to wear for hours text: Rating is 4.5 stars, see below for why I took 0.5 stars off.

I recently used this backpack over about 10 days of hiking, much of it in hot weather up and down some mountain trails. I wanted comfort: firstly not making my back sticky and hot, and secondly being easy to wear loaded for 6 or more hours in a day. It passed both criteria with flying colors. There are bigger and smaller sizes, so you can get just what you need for your purposes, they should be just as comfortable.

The minor negatives I have are: (1) Ideally there would be a few more small compartments for things like wallets and phones and keys. It's easy to lose things in the depths when small items are packed in with fleece pullovers and jackets and granola bars and such. (2) It's pretty hard to reach back to grab and pull out your water bottles: I ended up working with my travel partner to help each other out for this. I'd prefer a way to set those just a bit forward, and put the little waist packs behind perhaps.

Overall I'm sold on Osprey backpacks, and would buy one again quite happily.

title: I really like this probably as much at works I do at ... text: Ok, I like this probably as much at work, as I do at home, err hiking.

I work outside during all months of the year and go hiking year round. I use this at work to make a hot beverage or a hot meal on the job site. It take just a few minutes to boil the water and add it to a pre packaged meal. Sometimes its a 30 minute wide to the nearest store for the rest of the crew. I boil my water, let my meal go to cooking. MCheck my email, then eat and relax for 30 minutes before the other even think of getting back.

As to hiking, I use it basically for the same thing. hot beverage and or food. Its not even hard to cook for 3-4 people with it. Takes a couple more minutes but its easily doable.
I took the kids camping the other evening and my little one piped up, dad do we have any more left. I didn't expect to hear that.
Occasionally Ill have a meal that I don't accurately measure the water for and it become too wet or soupy, I don't mind soup but its something to watch for.

title: Great For Cleaning The Car Especially After Covered In Mud text: My daughter got her first car. It is used, but she is still at the point where she can wash, vacuum and clean her car often. When I got this cleanser, she grabbed it and ran.

WHAT IS THIS LIKE?
This cleaner comes in a large plastic bottle with 32 oz of cleaner in it. The scent is nice- almost like a gentle fruity smell with a twist like bubble gum- but not sickening at all.

HOW WAS IT USED
She used 3 caps into a bucket of warm water, and she washed as instructed.

PERFORMANCE?
This cleaner cleaned very well. It removed mud (when she got her car stuck in the mud it was completely covered), dirt, tar, and greasy spots without streaking. The car was left in great condition ready for polish. The surface was left clean with no residue as promised.

THE BOTTOM LINE
For a great cleaning for a car with no streaking or residue, this is good stuff. The fragrance is pleasant but not overbearing and it is easy to use.

MY RATING
FIVE STARS. A little goes a long way and the car looked great when done.

title: Great For Sledding or Sking text: My girls are 7 and 9 and they love these goggles for sledding. It's good to have some eye protection because they can't steer their sled very well and sometimes they end up in the bushes. It's pretty easy to get poked in the eye from a stick or a branch, and these are durable enough to deflect small hazards. They're also good for snowball fights.

The goggles are lightweight and flexible with good cushioning around the rim so your kids won't complain of discomfort. The strap is easy to adjust for a secure and comfortable fit. We had some issues with fogging, but I had good results with a spray lens treatment I use on my other skiing gear. You get two goggles and a carrying bag. Your kids will enjoy the protection these goggles give against bright snow, windburn, and the other common dangers of playing outside in the winter.

title: Why This Tent Is Special To Me-What Kind Of Camping It Is Good For (IN DEPTH REVIEW) text: WARNING= THIS IS A VERY IN-DEPTH REVIEW. FOR A BRIEF SUMMARY, SEE SECTION MARKED THE BOTTOM LINE
-------------------------------------
It was a time of great sorrow and difficulty as our family was dealing with the death of a dear and faithful friend. Sometimes it gets so overwhelming that we just wanted a place to get away. That is where this tent comes in. Let's take a look.

WHAT IS THIS TENT LIKE?
This tent is a beautiful aqua green color- sort of like seafoam green with a green fly and trim. I am going to review each aspect of this tent in a different section:

FABRIC
This is a thin tent. It has very thin but strong nylon. The floor is heavier than the rest of the tent, and the fly is slightly thicker as well.

SEAMS SEALED?
I was interested to see the seams of this tent sealed with observable shiny seal on the seams,, especially on the floor.

POLES
The poles are fiberglass on the top dome, and the side poles are metal.

CORNERS
The corner pieces are an intersection which is made from a plastic looking material. They have a prong that sticks out to hold the fly away from the tent.

CASE
The case is a squared case which zips shut and fits the tent, fly, and all of the pieces fit well into it. The instructions are also sewed into the case so you do not lose them and they won't get ruined by rain.

CEILING
The ceiling of the tent is a micro mesh. If you have a beautiful day, the top is gorgeous to leave open- even in warm weather with no threat of rain.

FLY
The fly is really nice. It is like in the picture, but what is really cool about this is that the fly has a LOT of room between the tent ceiling on the fly. It is water repellant and seems to hold up well if it is staked to the ground. The fly has a grommet which fits under the corner poles to help hold it down.

CLIPS
The tent and the fly have clips on them which snap onto the poles. They are plastic. I also opt to put a metal carabiner/D hook in the loop of the tent and fly and clip it around the poles for extra sturdiness.

FLOOR
Although this floor is sealed and is thicker than the rest of the tent, it still needs to have a tarp underneath- be careful not to let the tarp edges stick out or they can become a rain funnel. Leave an inch or two around the edges for run off should it rain.

WINDOWS
The windows of this tent do not zip. The back wall has no window. The sides have two large windows which have toggle closures. There are loops halfway down the edges so that you can either have the window closed, or halfway open. You can also have them rolled up and all of the way open.

FRONT WINDOW IN DOOR
The front window in the door has a zipper around it for easy closure. You can open that as much as you like.

FRONT DOOR
This has a two way zipper in it so that you can easily open to leave the tent or go back in without having to open the WHOLE door. You can also zip up to the lower corner to allow for electric cord should you need it.

CADDY
The caddy that comes with this has mesh pockets in it. There are quite a few storage areas and it will hold a lot of lightweight gear, glasses, phones, keys, etc. There are many loops around the edges of the tent to put the caddy so it is versatile.

LAMP HOOK
There will be a center hook in the ceiling for hanging a fan or lamp. There are rechargeable lamps and fans out there you can also use on this hook as well as traditional lanterns.

POCKETS
There are a few pockets sewn into the tend up off the ground as well as the caddy for plenty of storage.

CAN THIS BE PUT UP BY ONE PERSON?
That is the amazing thing about this tent. One of our kids put this up by herself. We wanted to test how hard it was and surprisingly, she did it without any help at all! The side poles have stakes in them which you push into the ground (not traditional stakes, but part of the pole itself). Once you do that the rest of the tent is easy to do, including staking the tent and the fly.

STAKES
The stakes with this are pretty shallow. They work in hard ground, but if you expect winds or are in sandy ground, I would suggest different stakes.

HEAD ROOM
This tent is fantastic for standing up in. Plenty of head room make it comfortable for dressing and moving around.

DOES IT FIT INFLATABLE MATTRESS?
We used a queen sized inflatable mattress and it fit (this is a four person tent) perfectly with enough room to walk around the edges and put backpacks and a few other items.

HOW MANY PEOPLE?
Although this says that it will fit four people, that would be a tight fit. For two people there is plenty of room for equipment and even a mattress, but for four people, you will have to be roughing it and squeeze in tightly. Three people would fit okay but again it will be roughing it and a bit tight.

WHY IS THIS SPECIAL?
This tent offered us a way to escape the stress of losing our friend and go camping in the yard. It is really comfortable for two people and it is bright colored and easy to use. We really enjoyed using it.

WIND
We had medium wind and the tent held up. I can not stress enough that you get GOOD stakes and stake everything down well - fly and tent.

RAIN
We did not have any rain the entire time we used this tent, so I can not report on severe storms. A light mist did not hurt it, but most tents won't be bothered by that. Severe wind with the rain will cause the windows to puff open at the top and you will get some spray if you don't run lightweight tarps down over then on the outside (secured on all corners).

WHAT IS THIS TENT BEST FOR?
This tent in my opinion would be best used for easy camping. Severe weather is not probably going to work well with this if sustained for a long period of time. Because of the lack of back window, the circulation is not as good as if it had one. However, for cooler weather, that is good- it allows for more warmth. I would say that this is a good tent for decent weather. It will stand up for a while under storms, but severe winds and driving rains more than a short stint would probably not leave this tent doing as well as a tent made for more severe weather.

THE BOTTOM LINE
For a really nice tent which is great for good weather camping, cooler weather camping, and brief occasional storms, this tent is a greeat choice. The color is refreshing, it is comfortable, has good storage and is well laid out. For more severe weather, I would not suggest it, but it will hold up for unexpected things now and then if you carefully stake it and set it up well.

MY RATING
FIVE STARS. If you use this for the weather it was designed for, this is an excellent tent. We love it. Then again, we did not have severe extended weather when we used it. I will update should I have anything to add in the future.

title: I dare you to get this back in the carry case, go ahead try. text: I thought this would be a great thing to take to the beach on our trip with the kids and grandkids. It looked very simple to put up. Not so much for me. After many cuss words, our daughter-in-law took over and set it up. It worked well for our day at the beach. Next, it came time to take it down and put it in its tiny little bitty carry bag. Come on, can't you make the carry bag bigger? I tried and tried, cussed and cussed, and finally threw it in the back of my Tahoe. When we got back to the rental house, I tried again, but no luck. I gave up and decided to donate it to the rental house.

The boy decided he might want it. So he and his wife got it back in the bag after I gave up and went to get a cool refreshing adult beverage.

It worked well for the day I needed it. Now the kids have one. LOL That carry case was way too tiny for me to get it back inside.

title: Bags feel too small.
text: I wanted to love this sleeping bag.  This bag is way too small for me.  I'm not some massive guy either.  I'm 5'10", 200lbs, but for some reason when I slip into this bag I can't move.  It's way too constricting for me.  Maybe I just need larger bags.  I'd probably say for thin people, this bag would be fine but if you have an athletic or overweight build, it's going to feel too small for you.  I've actually been using this bag more as a quilt in a pinch.  It is comfortable in that respect for me.  The stuff sack it goes in is not that great.  It ripped after very limited use.  The straps for cinching the bag closed do not hold as tight as you may want them too.  The straps will slip back to a position where they're comfortable so it's hard to compress the bag down as much as you'd like.  If you're an ultralight backpacker, there are lighter bags out there that are of better quality for sure.  Granted, you're going to pay a lot more though.
