title: Love this brand text: I found this brand for a chair and have decided to stick with them for more outdoor gear.

I have the double adult sleeping bag and it was packaged well and so was this bag. The storage bag these go into are well thought out and help keep it cinched down when storing/hiking.

The bag is quite cozy and I like this one better for warmth than the double bag because it’s less space to trap heat. The lining in the bag really limits the need for additional padding other than ground cover to limit dirt/sand directly on the bag.

The material seems to be made well here again and it is insanely comfortable and very warm/cozy.

The zippers work very well and there is a pull cord at the top to help cinch it closed or closer together on cold nights. It wasn’t difficult to roll back up and place in the bag. There were also no stitching issues either. We are very pleased with this purchase and it definitely makes camping easier if kids are excited just for the sleeping bag.

Much like my other review, I am super pleased here and we are going to get another to complete our sleeping bag needs for camping.

title: PERFECT For Hot Days When I Need Some Breeze text: Right after I got this, we got a heat wave. It was the perfect thing to get.

HOW DOES THIS COME?
This set of fans comes in a plastic liner that protects the fan unit and is housed inside of a cardboard box.

HOW THIS FITS
This fits around the neck and the fans will bend into place to point at the face or neck as you want them to.

HOW THIS TURNS ON
There is a tiny button on the right arm of this which you press three times for LOW MEDIUM AND HIGH and then one more time turns it off.

RECHARGE
To recharge this comes with a cord, and you only have to recharge it for a couple of hours for a full charge. A full charge lasts me about five hours for a mix of medium and low, although I used high for a few minutes in there too. On low it lasts longer than that.

IS IT COOLING?
I really like this. On a hotter humid day, I found that this really added a nice breeze to my face after being hot from working around the house. Sitting down to read a book or watch a movie is pretty nice.

IS IT LOUD?
This is very quiet, although on high, I did have to turn up the TV a little bit- not much.

LIGHT
The button has a blue light on it which does not turn off, so using this in the dark will make the blue light very obvious. To be honest, this is so quiet when it is on that the blue light helps me see if the button is accidentally pressed so it won't run down without me noticing it.

THE BOTTOM LINE
I love this for hot days. It works a long time on a charge, and the fans really do cool me off when I need it. I am thrilled to have this, honestly.

MY RATING
FIVE STARS. I like that this has a blue light so I can tell when it is turned on. The different speeds are great and even low is helpful on a warm day. I will be very glad to have this during the summer especially on days when there is no a breeze since we do not have air conditioning.

title: Excellent and high quality text: So I’ve got a lot of really great things to say about this treadmill. First off, I am a bit shy of gym’s and fitness centers right now, due to the ongoing situation in the world. But that same situation has definitely caused me to pack some weight on! I needed an answer, and I wanted something that was going to be solid to help me. This treadmill is that answer.

I don’t know much about treadmills, other than having used a few in my life, but I can say this stands out. A few really important things caught my eye, that I will add pictures of.

The first is a simple interface, everything is going touchscreen these days and I like buttons! This has simple to hit and adjust buttons – I can feel what I want to hit without constantly having to look down, I just know how to quickly adjust incline or speed, and don’t need to risk tripping over my own feet.

Additionally, I like the belt. This may sound silly, but a lot of lower priced treadmills expose the belt on the sides or the back – this is full enclosed. It feels safer if a dog, kid, or toy comes near the treadmill.

It also won’t operate without the key, which is an awesome safety feature.

The user interface is nice too – easy to see and explore the preset programs before you start your workout.

If folds up nice, but I think I will end up using it too much to fold up.

title: Good value considering the many features and smart software, but there's a big problem... text: Actually, I should say there are two problems, but I will concede only one of them is really a "big" problem. Let's start with the good:

When I first got the Charge HR, I was really happy with it and made use of all of the tracking features because I am a data addict and I was keen on getting a step counter combined with an accurate heart rate monitor that also did a few other neat tricks like track sleep. I particularly liked that it was able to tell when I was doing other exercise other than walking. I bike a lot so the fact that I can at least tell me how much cardio I am doing even when I am not putting in steps is very helpful. I never did do an accuracy check to see if the mileage recorded the mileage actually walked, but it's good enough for civilian use at any rate. I eventually stopped using the food calorie and water counter because it didn't integrate with other health software like MyFitnessPal, and just relied on steps, sleep patterns, calories expended and stairs climbed, all of which this watch does well along with the companion software. (I prefered to use the phone app vs. the web app.)

Then came my first disappointment. In addition to being pretty good at detecting when you are doing excercise automatically, you can also use it to manually track workouts to help you train and chart heart rate so you see how well you are pushing yourself, how long it takes to get yourself to peak HR, what your recovery cycle looks like, etc... afterwards, HOWEVER, there was no way for it just be in a mode where it would continuously show you your heart rate during a manual workout! This seemed crazy to me for a watch that was clearly designed to be an accurate HR monitor as well. When you are trying to use it as a real-time heart monitor this device totally fails because you need to fumble for the button or tap the screen repeatedly to get the heart rate which is a real distraction. It only will display one thing for several seconds. In some cases, like intense climbing while spinning, this is really not an option because you are using both hands for grip, so even if you configure it to use the single-tap to always show heart rate you can't really stop what you're doing to free a hand to do this. (Plus, this means a single tap always shows heart rate when you might want it to show you steps when not in explicitly set workout mode.) It would seem like this would be an obvious feature that could be made into a software update, but no such luck- at least not yet anyway.

The second one, and arguably maybe what is the deal-breaker is that after about 6 months of use, the charging contacts on the underside of the watch will not make a good contact with the charger cable anymore. I clean the watch according to the instructions but still had to resort to brushing the contacts with an old toothbrush in order for the cable to make contact to charge. Sometimes I had a scrape them with a knife! Sometimes a little water on the toothbrush helped, but not always. In any case, every time I charge it it is more and more of an ordeal and I am expecting before it is a year old it simply will not charge anymore no matter what voodoo ritual I perform to make it work. Maybe I have a dud, but this seems like it's simply a design flaw. This is where using an induction charging system where no metal-on-metal contact is required would be a obvious fix, and I'd expect you'll see this charging approach in later generation watches. I am thinking maybe this is the sign to get a more full featured watch that has GPS (either built in or linked with a phone) or perhaps something more multifarious like an Apple Watch. (Shudder to think!) Of course I would lose all my fitbit data, so I guess if I am going to change it up, I should do it sooner rather than later!

Anyway, that's the good, the bad, and the ugly on the Charge HR.

title: Vibrated off one too many times
text: For the good, I really enjoyed the visibility this mirror provided.  Once it snapped off though I realized just how much I relied on it.  After about a year of riding, it started vibrating up and off the sliderail.  I'd have to slam my brakes and hope a car didn't run it over.  Well, today it didn't just slide off, it completely snapped at one of the adjustment screws...and no, I hadn't made any adjustments to the angle or position in over a year.  It looks like the plastic just gave up and snapped cleanly, despite riding on a nicely paved asphalt road at the time.  It did last about 1.5 years, but something as simple as this, I'd have expected better.

title: Remarkably good taste, very easy to make and smells appetizing even dry text: This is just astonishingly easy to make and it tastes way better than expected. Usually dehydrated foods are flavorless and lifeless, but this chicken and dumpling concoction actually smells like chicken when you open the package and you can recognize the peas & carrots immediately. (see the photo)

I added the cup and a half of boiling water to the pouch per the directions, sealed the pouch and let it cook for 12 minutes. Opening the pouch releases a chickeny aroma and everything is sort of mushy and definitely cooked and ready to eat. The texture is fine - the chicken chunks are edible and not rubbery at all. The carrots & peas are fine as well. The only issue was with some of the dumplings - these are made of biscuits instead of noodle based and some of them were actually a bit crunchy. I'm not sure if this was deliberate or if maybe I should have used a little more water than the directions suggest. There's not real broth with the cup and a half - it's more like a bowl of porridge. The flavor is good and I didn't need to add any salt to this at all. I would consider adding a couple of these to our Hurricane Emergency supply kit for sure.

text: This windbreaker is super cute. It is gray with navy accents. There is a zipper down the front and on the pockets. The Adidas brand logo is on the front pocket. I like that it has a hoodie, which is great for those that need light protection in the fall or spring. It is lined, which is nice. It’s fashionable and you can pair it with jogging pants or jeans. The wrist and the bottom of the jacket have elastic, so it is secured and gives it a more athletic look. It is well made and holds up well for the active teen or adult. I’d recommend it.

title: Unusually long in the crotch and tight at the calves text: The Raypose High Waist Tummy Control Capri Yoga Pants have side mesh panels, pockets, and a unique fit. More about that later.

The material is dense, not see-through, and has a slight patina that is neither shiny or matte. I would call it more of a slight sheen.

The two mesh panels run the entire length of the outer legs and are only slightly see-through until you reach the pockets, which are lined, so your underwear will not be visible.

The pockets are only 3 1/2" wide and could not accommodate my XS Max, but may fit a smaller phone.

II received these leggings in size medium, but the fit is unlike any size medium I have tried before. I am 5'3", 116 lbs and wear a size small in bottoms, but I review size medium leggings all the time, and I am familiar with how it should fit my body.

When a size medium runs small, it will fit me at the crotch, and when it runs true to size, there is some bunching of excess fabric.

These do not even reach my crotch. I've never experienced that before. It reminded me of 60s style stretch pants with stirrups because the tight calves pulled the legs down and made them straight and taught. I was surprised by how snug the calves fit on my skinny legs.

I tried to pull them up as I high as possible to achieve a more comfortable fit, but the waistband reached to my bra line. Since I received them in a larger size, I rated these higher because I don't know if I would experience the same issues in the correct size, so I am giving them the benefit of doubt. Had these fit the same way in size small I would rate it at 3 stars.

I would recommend these for taller gals with long torsos and narrow calves.

** If you found this review to be helpful at all, please take a moment and click the button below to let Amazon know. Thank you 😊 **

title: loaded with nutrients, excellent addition to long term food pantry text: Get what you can, while you can. Spend now, or spend even more later (and that is if food is available). Doesn't need to be emergency packed food. Buy extra of what you like to eat every single time you are at the store, shop sales, go frequently (don't wipe out shelves). If you are at a spot where you want to add greater variety to put into long term storage, then Augason tends to have quality products and better prices than other emergency brands. Look for their sales, shop often, build up your supplies.

I like adding blueberries into the mix as it reconstitutes well, has good flavor and texture, and is still loaded with nutrients. Easy enough to stock up on rice and beans, harder to stock up on fruits and vegetables. Grow what you can, freeze or can what you can.. and buy what you can. Freeze dried is a very nice way to get good food that is still nutritious.

Most #10 (that reads, "number ten" not ten pound) cans will maintain freshness and quality for 10-25 years after production date. If opened, it will be shorter; depends on what you get. Blueberries in my experience are perfectly fine for a long time. Environmental factors will impact this. The cans are pest proof, can take a beating (even if dented should be fine as foods are freeze dried and have no moisture to sustain bacterial growth), can float if not opened, and are a standard size for stacking and uniformity (hence why weights will vary, and some stuff only fills a little of can).

title: Good for a Spontaneous Workout text: Exercise is important, as I am sure most would agree. But often, it isn’t practical to pay a visit to a nearby gym- you need something that is easily accessible and that you can take with you, wherever you go, for a quick workout. A good option for your workout needs is Portable Pilates Bar Kit with Premium & Upgraded 30LB Thick Resistance Bands.

Pulled from the package, this workout equipment is ready to use. All you need to do is attach the ends of the workout bar. At this point, you can use the foot loops to hold it down, then start exercising. There are several different ways you can use this simple piece of equipment. It can be used to tone different muscle groups depending on how it is used.

You do get a fairly good amount of resistance from this workout bar, but there is no way to control the level of resistance. You have to take it the way it is, since there is no way to adjust it, that I can see. It seems to work fine for basic needs. Once you have used it for a while, I would guess that will no longer be sufficient- it will get too easy and you will likely need something with greater resistance. In other words, this cannot take the place of the sophisticated workout equipment in a well- stocked gym. But the best part about it is that, since it is so small and compact, you can use it whenever you need it.

The best way to utilize the Portable Pilates Bar is to find different ways to do the exercises. I recommend going online and looking for different exercises so that you can workout different muscle groups. It’s a nice, simple piece of exercise equipment and it is useful for those who are on the go and need something to encourage exercise anytime, anyplace.

title: Kid friendly, and mother approved!
text: I have two wrestlers in my house. One in middle school and the other in high school. When they both expressed an interest, I immediately thought about the "cauliflower ear" that I have seen on some wrestlers. As a mother, one of the things that I worry about is my son's health, and in this case his ears. Investing in good ear protection is a must, so I set out to find the most protective headgear on the market. We purchased this same brand of headgear for my oldest son, and he has had absolutely no problems with it. According to my son, the Cliff Keen F5 Tornado Headgear is comfortable and he definitely feels protected. He says that he doesn't feel the impact of someone grabbing his head, and that it stays firmly in place. He finds that the straps on the top and under the chin are comfortable and keep the headgear in place without making it feel too restrictive. It also doesn't interfere with his hearing. He likes the way they look and how the ear portion is translucent and would allow him to see dirt. This headgear is easy to clean (usually he wipes them off with a Clorox wipe before wiping them off with a warm damp cloth and hanging them up to dry. The Velcro is sturdy and seems to be constructed to last a long time. Over all, I am satisfied with my purchase. For the money, I got a reliable product that gives me and my little wrestler peace of mind.

title: Love my table! text: I had recently purchased a used 8' Olhausen and reinstalled the original table covering. In anticipation of recovering one day, I wanted the experience with the previous cloth. But after having played on the table for a few months, I knew it was time to recover the whole thing. It's only been on the table for a week but I am completely satisfied with my installation (thanks Youtube and Legacy Billiards) along with the worsted ProForm 8' High Speed Professional Pool Table Cloth. It's like having a completely new table!!

Going from the original burgundy to tournament green was the right decision. My vision seems to be better and the worsted cloth allows me to actually apply english.

I completely when the extra mile before installing. The slate was gone over with a fine toothed comb and all deficiencies were addressed with a Bondo Glazing and Spot Putty. Along with one small adjustment to make the table as perfectly level as I could get.

If it wasn't for COVID-19 and 2020 I'd have family and friends joining me for much table enjoyment!!

First impressions are amazing with this product. It wasn't the most expensive or the least expensive worsted material but at present have no regrets.

title: Fantastic Paddle! text: I've tried several paddles and this is up there with my favorites. It has an elongated style with a 5.75" grip, which is the longest of any paddle I've tried. I personally would prefer a slightly shorter handle, but that is just my preference. I swing with one hand, but the longer grip is perfect for people who swing with both hands.

This paddle is among the thicker and heavier paddles I've used. It's 16mm and weighs ~8.5 oz. One of the first things I noticed when using this is the large sweet spot. I didn't expect an elongated paddle to have such a large sweet spot, so it was a welcomed surprised. The carbon fiber used in this paddle is supposedly 66% stronger than the carbon fiber used in most other pickleball paddles, but I couldn't tell a difference.

If you're looking for a great paddle with a longer grip, this is it!

title: excellent fit on my tall, super plus sized frame; very comfortable text: I went with the size XXL because the size chart in the pictures states that XXL is size 20/22. I'm pretty much a size 20. I took my chance on this because sometimes things just don't fit right or feel right. I am SO glad that I got these- the sizing is perfect. I can tell it can stretch more (but hopefully wont need to). When they arrived, my initial thought was that they won't fit. But I put them on with ease. The polyester spandex blend is perfect. It is snug without being constricting. It is compressing without feeling like being encased like a sausage. My lower belly apron (flab) appreciates the additional support.

High waist keeps the capris in place. I find that I do not need to hike them up. I can sit, bend, run around, and they aren't falling off. This is important because I am tall (5'10", 300lbs), and sometimes the way clothes are made are meant for shorter frames, or so called high waists roll, etc. So this pair of capris is rather perfect for me.

Gusseted crotch lends to extra comfort, ease of movement, and not as much strain on the seams.

The pockets are functional yet aren't noticeable when not in use. They lay flush. Surprisingly deep.

The color gray, depending on lighting has more of a purple undertone. I like it a lot, even more so than the dull light gray I often see. I really like it paired with a black shirt.

The material is thin enough to feel light and breathable, yet has plenty of coverage. I could make out my underwear line, but not my underwear. The mesh is not revealing; it looks more like a pattern.

I find these to be very comfortable, and am pleased with the overall look, fit, and feel. As a plus sized person, it means a lot to find something that I feel good in. I am highly considering another pair or two in different colors.

Again, very happy to have tried this, and now I have another brand I can count on.

title: Can't watch HR - Updated text: My husband bought me that s watch for my birthday. The watch is very classy and practical. The app to track information like sleep and heartrate are very informative. The issues I have with it are that the heart rate, which is my main use, is not practical. It's not very accurate and I can't watch it as I need to.nYpu have to ouch on the watch through options to get to it then it closes out after a few seconds. I need to watch my heartrate as needed and I can't do that with this watch and for that reason alone may have to return it. I have an issue called POTS and when I stand my blood doesn't go where it should and my heart works very hard to fix the issue which results in dizzy spells, exhaustion, high heart rate and mental clarity.
The other issue is how hard it is to take links out. The tool included broke fairly quickly so I had to buy a kit to continue.
Update: I wore the watch for a few days. After 2 days I had to charge it. On the 3rd day, the watch was dead before the end of the day. This is the last straw. I conclude that this watch just does not cut it. I hope this review helps.

title: Poor quality control, apparently
text: I spent all the time setting this thing up, and when it was finally ready to go, the up/down resistance buttons had no effect on the bike.  I pulled it apart to double check and yep, it was hooked up correctly.  After a while of pressing, the down button on the bike is now broken (and no, I didn't start pressing harder to make it work, I know that won't have any effect on electronics).  Apparently wasn't made to endure a few dozen presses.  If I decided to keep it, I am now stuck with a bike that operates at one level of resistance.  I'm glad I bought it from a local retailer's online pickup...I love Amazon but I was worried of this very thing--if I needed to make a return I'd have to pay shipping at amazon, and this thing is HEAVY.  Do yourself a favor and pay a little more for a Schwinn.  It has program options, I'm sure better reliability (can't be any worse, right?), straps on the pedals and the option to plug it in if you want.  This thing is garbage.  Maybe you'd get lucky and get a good one.  Maybe not.  You've been warned.

title: Knife-like edge is USELESS but spoon & fork are usable text: I ordered their [[ASIN:B07M8K5VQ8 Titanium spork]] and decided to order this pair as well since it was cheaper and I needed an extra one for my boyfriend when I do day trips.

This is a thick plastic spork that is just somewhat stronger than a typical plastic utensil. It is BPA-free and is food and dishwasher safe. There is a fork on one end with one of the tines that has a "knife-like" edge. There is a spoon on the other end. The center holes can be used to fasten this to a backpack using the reusable teather it comes packaged with.

I got this because many times when I go on a staycation, I pack a cooler with yogurt and stuff for day travel. This is perfect for that. I ate with the spoon and fork fine but I could not cut anything of substance with the knife. I think $4.99 is reasonable for what this is but the knife-like edge is completely useless. A butter knife cuts better. However, the spoon and fork are good for any "away-type" eating such as camping, backpacking, or just a staycation with a cooler in tow.

Even though the price is right, the reason I give this 3 stars is because the knife is useless and the thick plastic has a different mouth feel and pick-up ability. For instance, when I was eating yogurt with the spoon, I could not scrape the container as easily with the spoon end as I could with the [[ASIN:B07M8K5VQ8 Titanium Spork]]. This is good enough but neither their Titanium spork or this one is great.

I attached two pictures. The first photo is of this set and the second photo is with my Titanium version on the right end for comparison purposes.

title: Packaged well text: I found that the packaging was a lot of the work when getting this project started. It seems they really focused on this as others mentioned issues with packaging.

The directions are better than most, but still not perfect. It does show you what to do but the explanations are missing depth. Overall I'd rate this as an intermediate level of expertise. A lot of that expertise is going to come from removing some of the equipment from the golf cart (versus the assembly of the seat to the golf cart).

I was not thrilled with the thinner material (I purchased a seat for a previous golf cart that had a bit thicker steel and the seats were a bit more durable). The seats do need self tapping screws to install into the thin diamond plate steel but it does look good. The handle that comes with the seat seems to provide structural support for the thinner steel rather than convenience. Though it does provide a more secure look to the cart.

IMPORTANT PART: The bigger issue I'm having now that it's all assembled is more and more cities are requiring rear seats to have seat belts. I had planned to install them as I did on my prior seat on my previous cart. That seat had bolt holes that seemed to plan for seat belts. This does not have holes for the belts and trying to find reasonable areas on the seat or cart aren't working. It seems like I'll be tapping some new holes to get those installed.

Outside of that I still did rate this well as it is a good looking seat once on the cart. The instructions are solid overall. The packaging was also done well (2 boxes too). I would recommend this to others.

title: Works much better than drops of Clorox bleach text: Typically I would use bleach to clean my reservoirs, but it is fairly powerful and leaves an aftertaste if you aren't very careful. These have no such problem - one or two tabs, leave it overnight, takes care of everything for you. Gets rid of the biofilm that may have built up over months of storage, helps ensure that even after you've used your cleaning kit to get rid of visible buildup, you don't have other harmful organic particles floating around in there.

You can still use chlorine bleach on particularly tough cases, but one or two of these per year will do the trick on anything you usually use.

Wouldn't recommend using this to preserve water, though - they are a bit too strong for that. I use Katadyn Micropur MP1 tabs (ASIN: B000H3DNF4) for that purpose.

title: Not usable for most applications text: It’s a good concept, but the execution is poor for larger straps. If you store more than one fold of the sling the magnets aren’t powerful enough to hold on. When using a blue force sling it is basically useless. Regardless of where you try it, foregrip or the stock, it cannot hold the sling in place. A heavy duty rubber band is more effective than this at holding large straps.

I also believe the company is using a common practice of identifying an American made product, while not outwardly saying Made in America. I understand that an American flag doesn’t always mean made here, but this style is commonly used for such purposes. Seeing as the company's profile is based out of China I would safely say this product is made there.

Overall, I wouldn’t recommend this product for most. If your strap is very narrow and you would have at most one fold over it might work but be aware that if it rubs against something the magnets will let go. I would like to see the company use stronger magnets or possibly a small strip of Velcro to assist the magnets. In the meantime I will sew some Velcro to my existing one.

There are tent-style pegs and loops to stake it into the group which is great to avoid having it shift from movement or wind blowing over it, and the material is super thin so it actually folds up rather easily into a remarkably small carrying pouch. This is SO MUCH better than the thick blankets we used to use, I highly recommend it!

title: Didn't work that well
text: We went to Italy for 2 weeks and I got these for that trip.  I didn't want to have to keep wasting plastic water bottles so thought these would work better since we could just refill them.  They were hard to clean initially since neither of my 2 bottle brushes that I have would fit inside these to clean them.  I did follow the directions for boiling them and then cleaned them with hot water and soap.  The first day I used them in Rome when we went to the Colosseum, the clip on the first bottle broke.  That was the first time using that bottle.  I was using the clip to hang it on my bag and when I first took it off to give the kids some water, the clip completely broke off and I wasn't able to hang it on my bag anymore.  It was also difficult to clean during our trip since it has such a small opening and no brush or sponge will fit inside.  We weren't always at places where I had access to a stove to get boiling water going.  So we ended up not using them after the first couple of days since it wasn't really convenient.  I did like that when you are not using them, you can roll them up and use the attached silicone strap to keep them rolled up.  I really wanted to love these and had planned on using them a lot during our vacation but sadly that did not happen.  The idea is good but not the actual use.

title: Well Made and Lightweight text: I selected this holster to go with a Glock 17. I wanted it more for protecting the piece rather than concealed carry, and for that it seems to be just fine. I have not had this very long and I haven't worked with it much but so far I am pleased with it.

The holster is lightweight, made of Kydex which feels a lot like plastic but is more durable while not adding significant weight. It seems to be assembled well and the screws holding it together are tight. Nothing shifts or moves that shouldn't, and that's a good sign. So far, I have no complaints with the assembly.

I am very especially pleased that it is made such that the trigger is completely concealed and inaccessible, so that you can't pull it out with your finger on the trigger which is a common mistake.

The Glock for which it is designed fits perfectly, snapping in place nicely without requiring a lot of effort to put it in or pull it out, but still connecting tightly enough to keep it from falling out accidentally.

The holster is low profile so it is well suited for concealed carry. It clips firmly to a belt and it is easy to conceal when properly equipped.

I like this holster and so far I am pleased with it. It seems to be made very well, if fits the intended piece perfectly and it is lightweight so it doesn't add appreciable weight. If you are looking for a lightweight and rugged holster, this is a good one to consider.

title: A Different Use For This Senior Citizen text: Some folks my age are into aerobics, jogging, weight lifting, and the like. Me, I'm much more sedentary and have no inclinations toward even something as basic as step aerobics. Nope, I have a very different use for this exercise step, one that is important to me. My bathtub is on an 8" riser making it unnecessarily harder to get in and out of. A physical therapist suggested I get an exercise step to make using the bathtub easier. That was an excellent idea and this step works well for that, with a few caveats.

On the plus side, the step feels sturdy to stand on and doesn't slide around. The extra risers allow me to set it at the height that works best for me. A few minor things keep me from giving it a full five stars though. For one thing, this step is very long, making it a bit unwieldy in my smaller bathroom. For another thing there's no handle for easy lifting. Back in the day when I did work out in a gym, they would stack steps like these along a back wall when the aerobics classes were not in session. So the steps were being picked up and moved around a lot. A handle on the side would make that a little easier to do. Finally, some of the plastic under the step seems a bit cheap and brittle. I don't know how that will hold up under extended use. All in all though, this step is doing exactly what I needed it to do and for that I have to give it four stars.

title: A Windproof Umbrella, Who KNEW? text: When I got this, my daughter asked me why in the world I would get something so weird. I put it in the car and told her you never know when it will come in handy. Little did we know, it would be a few hours later that we would find out how handy it was!

WHAT IS THIS UMBRELLA LIKE?
This umbrella is well packaged. It comes with a nylon sleeve. This nylon sleeve slips into a faux leather sleeve for extra protection and that upscale executive look. The umbrella has a button that snaps it open along with the stem which gets longer too. There are a LOT of ribs in the umbrella and it is black fabric which is thicker than many of the thin ones you often see out there.

HOW DOES THIS PERFORM?
When we arrived at our destination, suddenly, it began POURING. We had to park really far away, and we did not have a lot of rain protection. I whipped my umbrella out of the back seat much to my daughter's horror.
"WHAT ARE YOU DOING?? That is gonna RUIN that umbrella!!"
I responded, "Well, we will see if does what it claims"

I grabbed the umbrella on the stem above and below using both hands and we used it to walk to the building we were going to. Believe it or not, that umbrella did not even flinch at the horrendously high winds and rain. Even I was surprised.

THE BOTTOM LINE
Well, so far, I have tried this in very extreme conditions and it held up beautifully. It did not flinch when tilted against the wind and protected us from the rain. So far I am impressed.

MY RATING
FIVE STARS. This one did perform way better than expected in the most extreme conditions I would ever dare test it in.

title: Neosport XSPAN Neoprene Wetsuit and Accessories for all of my Swim and Endurance Training Needs
text: This Neosport XSPAN 3/2mm Men's Wetsuit fits me almost perfectly, and that is amazing.  I didn't naturally trim down this past spring after putting on all the holiday weight last fall and winter.  I was 5' 11'' tall, with a 38'' waist, covered by a 44'' gut, and a 47'' chest. I have fairly broad shoulders but not very thick shoulders or biceps.  Out of the box, from chest down to my ankles this wetsuit fit me perfectly.  I just have just a very little extra room in the shoulders and biceps area.  The Neosport Xspan Neoprene is so unbelievably comfortable compared to the material in an H20 shorty, a Mares shorty, the comparable O'neil full wetsuit, and the Zoot Triathalon wetsuits that I tried on thanks to Amazon Prime. The extra room around my shoulders and biceps has made swimming for long distances much easier (in a harness in my 68 degree lap pool). There is no chafing at all.  I also wear a 20 Lb. Gold's Gym Weighted Vest over this wetsuit to counteract the flotation of the suit so I'm a little deeper in the water for a tougher workout - an hour long swim. The pounds are coming off and I am hoping my next wetsuit will be the XL size of this same wetsuit by the time it's too cold to swim in my pool in late November or December, unless I go to the XL in the thicker 5mm XSPAN Neoprene to keep swimming all winter.  I'll definitely keep this wetsuit for my heavier weight seasons, and the next one for my more trim size.  I also loved that the NeoSport accessories all fit perfectly; the Premium 5mm Hi Top Zipper Boots (11), the Premium 2mm Hi Top Socks (11), the Premium Neoprene 5mm 5-finger XL Gloves, and the Premium 5/3mm XXL Vented Bib Hood.

title: Get one now text: The hammy band is the unsung hero! This seemed to hit the market with a bellyflop in that it made a loud smack but that was about it. This product has gone under the radar but has been highly effective.

I have had radiating hip pain that has traveled down my leg. I've tried using different modalities to loosen the area and buy space for additional ROM that is pain free or nearly pain free. The hammy band has definitely helped in that regard because it provides that additional tension on the troubled area WHILE being in motion. This has allowed the muscle to free up and the nerve to move properly as well (less tingly pain lately).

I do use this for every leg session and have been able to return to light squatting after 3 years of problems coupled with "solutions" that always failed after weeks of consistent practice.

Hammy Band ftw

title: Nice Lightweight Sleeping Bag Not For Very Cold Weather text: You might be wondering why I would want a sleeping bag that is clearly not designed for multi-season use. Let's take a look.

WHAT IS THIS LIKE?
This sleeping bag is really two bags zipped together. There is a nice outer and inner layer which are slick yet soft enough to sleep in. You can use them together or apart and in single bag style. The zipper works well and seems to hold well at this point.

HOW BIG IS THIS?
This is big enough to go onto our queen sized inflatable mattress for our tent and also the one that we use indoors.

WHAT WILL I BE USING THIS FOR?
We only do camping on our yard for the most part during the summer months when it is hot and we don't want to sleep indoors. Sometimes, I get tired of the sheet or light blanket sliding off the mattress, so having this bag will be great for those chilly nights that sometimes come after a hot day.

Also, I plan to have this handy because of a situation where we have to be prepared to sleep overnight out of town due to someone we know with health issues who might need someone to stay with them for a while. There is an inflatable mattress at the house and having this sleeping bag makes it easier to set up and take down quickly to get going with the day.

IS THIS COMFORTABLE?
It is a sleeping bag. If you have two people who have different sleeping issues- sprawling vs thrasing, for example, this could be frustrating. If you have two sleepers who sleep relatively calmly, this is fine. I did not find it uncomfortable for light sleeping. I did have to be careful about lumps and wrinkles due to it being lightweight. It was not too bad though.

IS IT HARD TO PACK?
This can be packed as a double bag or single ones and rolled up using strap or belt for both or separately. It is not difficult to roll up and compacts pretty well. When I really work at it, I can get it pretty small for packing in the car.

IS THIS WARM?
As I said, this is not what I would call a WARM bag. It is warm enough for a summer or early fall sleep outside when the nights might reach down into the upper 40s or low 50s. I would not use this for really cold snaps, or at least bring extra blankets or dress warmly if that is the case.

THE BOTTOM LINE
This bag is great if you need a quick sleeping arrangement for two people or to go on top of a queen sized inflatable mattress. It is easy to set up and pack and can be broken down into two bags. It is plenty warm for summer, but not for really cold nights.

MY RATING
FIVE STARS. This is good for my purposes, but if you plan to use this for heavy duty camping in cold weather, you might want to bring blankets, or pick another bag.

The handlebars have a combination of a quick release lever and a locking system so you can safely raise the bars. My youngest daughter is 4' 2" and she fit this scooter very well. title: finicky and fragile text: I've had this stove for twenty years. I really like what I've done with the stove, and all the amazing exploits I've had with it might cause me to reminisce fondly of it, but the fact is it leaves a lot to be desired. Yes, it worked to melt snow at extreme altitudes. Yes it worked as nearly my entire kitchen on multi-week treks in the backcountry. Yes, it survived 20 years and still works dependably, sort of.

I can only remember being well and truly frustrated with it one time, on backcountry ski trip. It was storming outside the tent, and I was at high altitude. I only filled the bottle with about an inch and a half of fuel because it was only an overnighter. The bloody thing would not stay lit. After that, I bought a smaller bottle to avoid problems with a low fuel level. I also bought a larger bottle for multi-week trips.

This is a stove that rarely works at its best. Most of the time it manages to work acceptably. Some of the time it works poorly. It was rare that it worked truly bad.

I always used white gas in it. It's fairly efficient so I never had an experience where I ran out of fuel, or if I did, it was inconsequential because it was on the last day or something. I'd be more concerned with running out of isobutane with one of those systems.

This stove system is both finnicky and fragile. It really works well if the stove is in just the right condition, with the bottle filled just the right amount, the stove level, the bottle at the proper angle for the pick-up tube, and at the right pressure.

Despite the stove itself being very tough, the plastic bottle valve doesn't stand up. The replacements are expensive, and the reviews for that replacement show a consensus that these things have problems. I would say the reviews for those replacement pumps are probably more accurate and unbiased than the ones for the stove.

I have a MSR Reactor for a couple years now. It simply blows the Whisperlite away in terms of melting snow or boiling water. It's far simpler, almost stupid-proof, way faster, and practically just as light and compact when you factor the fuel bottle and pot.

More recently, I acquired a Trangia alcohol stove. As a minimalist with a preference for ultralight style, it was appealing. I don't have extensive experience with it yet. I bought it to simmer and cook, which the Whisperlite and Reactor don't do well at all. While the Trangia would be slower to melt snow or boil water (the forte of the Reactor, and Whisperlite), I believe it would still do the job under practically all the conditions I'll encounter. Alcohol is a far more appealing fuel to carry than white gas or isobutane.

At this point, I have a broken bottle valve. It works, but the plastic clips to retain the pump plunger are broken. For less than the price of a replacement part, I acquired the Trangia stove that I will likely use for the next 20 years. It's lighter, cleaner, easier to use, simmers nicely, and takes less space in the pack.

title: Decent soft flask, but difficult to close text: I use this bottle with my Salomon 1L running vest. As soft flasks go, it is okay. I prefer the types of flasks which have a larger opening, as it makes it easier to clean, but the wide mouth really doesn't serve the kind of purpose to which it is typically put.

The most significant issue is that it is very difficult to close - to secure the lid you have to apply significant twisting force to it and the bottle,, but the only surface you have to grab onto on the flask is the collar right under where the flask threads on, which is of course flexible. If you grab lower, then the squeezing pressure forces the water out the top of the flask. You can tighten it, but it takes several seconds and some technique, whereas on any other bottle it is maybe a second and practically zero effort. The collars on the official Salomon flasks (ASIN: B07V7J8R8F) are approximately elliptical in shape and a little stiffer, so you can get a solid grip, and the caps go on as easy as any other bottle.

The second issue is how it fits into the vest. In a Salomon vest, the circular lid doesn't really fit well - it protrudes awkwardly (in terms of how it feels and how it looks) from the top of the sleeve, and it only gets more awkward as the water in the flask decreases. It fits, but not as well as the official Salomon flasks, which have that oblong collar and narrow cap, which has no such issue.

So this is okay for a generic soft flask, if you want to keep it in your pocket or bag and collapse it when it is empty. Much more convenient than hard plastic bottles for that purpose. However, for a running vest, try the Salomons or flasks of a similar design instead.

title: IN DEPTH Review Of This Backpack text: WARNING- This is an IN DEPTH review of this backpack to help those who are trying to make serious buying decisions. If you prefer a more brief summary, please see section marked THE BOTTOM LINE
----------------------------
When it comes to summer time and even Spring or Fall, my family loves to go for hikes. Sometimes it involves overnights. The talk of the family has been to want to bring a backpack along with tent and sleeping arrangements on an overnight hike in some great land around some lakes. I knew that our usual backpacks would not suffice, so when I saw this, I thought it would be perfect. Let's see how this measures up to what we need.

WHAT IS THIS BACKPACK LIKE?
The backpack has a very thick woven black fabric that is more like what you would find in a heavy jacket. It is not thin nylon that is sometimes found in backpacks. The black fabric is rugged. There is a sizeable gusset (10 inches) in the bottom which can be retracted with adjustable straps. These straps can hold a bedroll, small personal tent, or other similar things. The straps are pretty long so I am thinking the capacity is quite adaptable. That means you can pack a small personal tent AND bedroll or portable small cot (we have one that would fit perfectly here).

SIDE POCKETS
There are two small net pockets which can hold water bottles or similar things, and also side long zipped pockets which have cords on them for easy quick access. The zipped pockets are angled, but they measure 9 inches tall at widest point. The highest point is 10 inches.

ADJUSTABLE STRAPS
There are quite a few pair of adjustable straps:
- under backpack
-upper sides
-small circular straps at upper edge of back pocket
-from backpack to top of shoulder straps on the front (possibly can hold small roll of some sort)
-center of each shoulder strap to hook and hold backpack in place
-on padded waist belt to hold in place
-at base of padded waist belt to hold backpack to waistband for security
-in between shoulder straps in loop form to hang backpack from

BACK CENTER COMPARTMENT
This pocket has a tough handle on it so that you can lift the pack out when it is zipped. Inside there are three pocket compartments- two netted and one nylon. Compartment is 11 inches high, and pockets are- nylon: 7 1/2 high and nylon are 6 inches high and 5 inches wide each. The compartment itself is a little over 10 inches wide. The entire compartment has a double two way zipper which means that you can open it down each side or the entire way by sliding both heads to one side.

TOP BACK COMPARTMENT
This compartment is at the top of the back. It is about 9 x 9 approximately. This pocket has a place with a strap and a plastic/nylon hook so you can hang keys from it if you need to. The gusseting in the pocket allows bulky items to be put in this pocket. It is not too deep or too shallow to be practical.

PADDING AND SHOULDER STRAPS/HARNESS
The padding on this is great. The back itself is reinforced and very stiff, yet comfortable. It has plenty of padding on it for comfort while walking with a loaded pack. The straps have great padding on them as well. There is plenty of padding on the waist belt as well, with extra padding on the small of the back for comfort and ease of walking with support.

MAIN COMPARTMENT
This compartment is very deep and only has an elasticized pleated pocket in it which is on the reinforced back panel (the one that goes on your back when wearing the backpack). The entire compartment is approimately 22 inches in depth. The elasticized pocket inside is about 10 inches high. Width of back panel is about 12 inches. The compartment can extend up to 12 inches out if packed fully. There is another hook in this compartment to hang keys from etc.

WATER BAG
If you want to carry a water bag in the backpack, it would fit in here, and there is a little hole that you can slip the tube through for drinking. We do not use a water bag at this point so I can not comment on the usefulness of this feature.

WORKMANSHIP
This backpack seems to be made in top quality workmanship. The sewing is great, no loose threads, and all of the bindings and zippers seem to be in very well with no gaps or missed stitches.

OUR EXPERIENCE WITH THIS BACKPACK
So far, we have just had all day hikes with this- no bedroll or personal tent yet as it has been way too snowy and cold so far. However, as a backpack in general, we have packed this thing up well. I also did take it to a large fiber festival which required me to slip things rolled up into the straps and also to pack the backpack pretty well. It was easy to walk in and comfortable as well. I spent almost an entire day with it and it did not make me all stiff at the end of the day like some packs will do.

UPDATES
I will be updating this as we have a chance to use it over the summer for camping and serious overnight hiking as well.

THE BOTTOM LINE
Made with excellent workmanship, tough fabric, and well thought out, this backpack is great for hiking, even if a personal tent and/or bedroll or cot is desired to carry with you on a trek. Use of water pack is possible with this backpack although we have not used it in that capacity as of yet. The padding is comfortable and supportive and the backpack itself is easy to pack and carry if you are careful how you set it up for most balance and comfort as with any backpack.

MY RATING
This is five stars. It seems like it will meet our needs perfectly and I will update when I have more experiences to add to this review if applicable.

title: Fabulous! text: This is a fantastic add-on to my bike!

The directions for installing were a bit confusing, so eventually I just set them aside and used commonsense - the goal is to align the top of the shelf to the top of your exercise console...the tighter the fit, the better the hold. This is incredibly easy to do, if a little time consuming, I did play with the fit/positioning a little, but overall it took me about 30 minutes to get this set-up the way I wanted it. I have a exercise bike, with a full seat, not the bicycle looking one; this fit right on the center console (it blocked my view of the console, which is fine seeing as how the battery has been dead for months) and I used the two straps to loop it tightly around/over the handle bars.

The one bad thing about it, has nothing to do with the product itself....my exercise bike wobbles a little, especially at fast pace, and since this is tied right to the bike, the laptop then wobbles. I obviously don't do major computing while exercising, so this didn't bother me too much. My typical internet use while on the bike is netflix or facebook, if I happen to be reading something I just zoom the browser to make reading easier.

Already recommended this to a few friends who also love it!

title: Perfectly sized. text: I hate carrying objects in my hand with me when I go for a run or a jog. It adds weight, even if it's minuscule, but my mind starts to play tricks on me and says it's weightier than it really is, and it affects my pace. This, fortunately, fits the bill for when I want to take water on the go, which is usually during marathons or such.

The bottle is a bit tight upon first fit, and still is a bit so even after I've properly fit it, but I'm wondering if it will stretch out over time. The weight with the water is fine. It's not too much because the plastic bottle is slim and conforms to the palm, but after it's been drunk a bit the sloshing inside gets kind of annoying. But that's another effect from my brain playing tricks on me.

Otherwise, it's the optimal way to carry water with me without adding a substantial-enough amount of weight to play tricks with my mind.

title: Pay attention to sizing... text: I got this set for my husband, as he is an avid swimmer at our local pool. The sizing was different than what we expected. The fins were the L/XL size we were looking for, but the mask came in a small. Unfortunately, the mask was too tight for my husband to use. However, the fins work great. He loves the smaller size and said they are easier to maneuver around the pool vs. his extra long fins.

I went with him to the pool one night so I could try out the snorkel mask. We are both dive certified and snorkel whenever we get the opportunity to do a fun beach vacation, so I thought this mask would be great. It felt a bit awkward to use when you are used to a normal snorkel. It made me feel a bit claustrophobic. I also couldn't see as clearly as my regular snorkeling glasses. title: Perfect for short rides text: This is a great hip pack, and it is big enough to carry a tube, pump, snacks, multi tool, snacks, and phone, along with a water bottle. Mine is 4.5 lbs fully loaded, and it sits comfortably while biking and walking. I like using this for rides up to 2 hours (in current mild/cold weather where I don’t drink as much water). I’ve used a hydration backpack for many years, and it is nice to get the weight off my shoulders. If I need more than 24 oz of water, I’ll use my camelbak.

I tried the Osprey Seral 4 before getting the Savu 2, but issues relating to the hydration bladder (it didn’t sit flat on my back when full) and hose (the magnet wasn’t strong enough, it would constantly dangle precariously by my spinning wheel, and I couldn’t easily take a drink while moving) were too big, and I stopped using it after a few rides. This Savu 2 doesn’t have those issues, and I enjoy using it a lot more than the Seral 4. There is less storage space in the Savu 2, but it is enough for shorter rides.

title: Really cool glasses text: Wow these are lightweight glasses - very first thing I noticed was how light they were.

The polarization is nice too. They give you a little tester piece so I took pictures for this review to show you how it works. Super cool seeing the effect that polarized glasses have.

The transition of the glasses is nice too. Walking around outside I could appreciate the difference between walking in my dark garage and then outside in the sun.

title: Good gear - transparent, functional. text: I got the base rack, this extension, the workstand, the HiLo (extension), and a hitch lock. It's good stuff. I wanted to get the Sherpa but my wife wanted the ability to haul friends' bikes, too. She drives a Jeep Wrangler and I have to admit that it is fun to pile into her toy car with the top and doors off and go on adventures like high school.

I was concerned that this one is so heavy that she wouldn't be able to remove/install it by herself, or even operate it. It's easy enough for anyone to operate, and we just leave it on. For people with short arms and this extender installed, you will have to figure out how to stand to be able to reach the latch. My wife is 5'0" and she can raise and lower the rack and get her own e-bike onto the rack. She lifts the front tire onto and just rolls it into place.

The hardware that holds the bikes is easy to use and reliable so far. We drove from Kansas City to Des Moines, IA (2.5hrs) for a weekend and the bikes didn't budge.

There isn't much to say about gear like this - there are no issues. Everything works like you would expect, and it vanishes into the background.

Oh, one gripe - they don't offer a lock that both holds the HiLo firmly AND is keyed the same as the rack/extension.

title: Excellent holster for the Dan Wesson 4 inch from Amazon
text: The holster is made of a very tough plastic vinyl material which should last a lifetime, and it fits the Dan Wesson 4" like a glove.  My only problem with the holster was that the retaining strap which snaps in the back, is a little too short and is not a true "thumb break".  I had to stretch the retaining strap quite a bit with a little heat from a hair dryer to get it to snap at all, and if you unsnap the strap and pull the gun while wearing the holster, it is almost impossible to snap it back with one hand.  I gave it five stars because it is 99% functional (the strap) and it looks very cool.

title: Heats up quickly/Easy to hold text: This hand warmer has proven very effective as an aid to relieve symptoms of Ray Naud’s Syndrome (White Finger). I use it when walking outside and it has been so helpful in relieving the symptoms of vaso constriction in my fingers. I have asked several of my friends to tell me what they think as they have similar symptoms and they asked me where to get it. They both found the item very comfortable to hold, and the heat relaxing. It fits nicely in my jacket pocket. The only suggestion I have is to provide two as a set asI find myself switching from hand to hand. Overall, I find this product very useful and I am using it regularly when walking and also in the car when it is very cold outside.
Christine

title: Size !!!
text: You see the product description up there where it says 5 and up twice?! Yes? Well, this helmet is not sized 5+, like you might think. Nope. It is size 8+. It is difficult to buy helmets online because no one posts something as simple as the size of the helmet. So, your sitting there thinking this helmet is a 5+ because it keeps saying 5 and up in the description, you order the helmet for your 5 year old, you get the helmet and it is 8+. So, if you are looking for a 8+ helmet, this is for you. If you are looking for a 5+ helmet, better luck next time.

title: Big, Practical Tote With Carrier That Fits Large Yoga Mats text: This GAIAM EVERYDAY YOGA TOTE (with Yoga Mat Carrier Sleeve) is a big, practical, black nylon tote with gray polyester lining. It wipes clean with a damp cloth. Inside, it has a big zippered pocket and two big open-topped pockets; outside, it has a magnetic-closure patch pocket on the mat carrier.

The mat carrier holds a [[ASIN:B07HB1JL16 classic Gaiam yoga mat]], of course, and also fits my larger and thicker [[ASIN:B07JMJ1YZM Incline Fit Premium Anti-Slip Yoga Mat]]. Your mat must be rolled tightly to fit, but you want a snug fit so that the mat won’t slide out of the carrier when you’re headed to yoga class. (The carrier is a tube of fabric rather than a flap or strap, so it won’t fit really big, thick mats--not even the [[ASIN:B07H9PZDQW Gaiam thick yoga mat]].)

The tote is extremely well made. It also comes with a clip-on shoulder strap.

title: I love this case
text: I love this case.  It's the easiest waterproof case to put on an iphone I've ever had.  It comes in two simple pieces...front and back. The back is clear just like the front, but it fits quite simply onto the front section and the two seal together by pressing it all around with your thumb.  I've called family members who tell me the sound quality is good, not muffled. The case comes with a wrist strap, a lanyard for wearing it around your neck, a screen cloth and an instruction booklet. Very nice package and excellent price.  I'm thrilled with this case. My biggest problem is dropping my phone and this rubber bumper around the edge is perfect for protecting it. The bumper extends enough on front and back to protect the screen.  There's also a bumper around the light and the camera lens. At first I had a little trouble getting the Home button to respond, but with a few tries, that problem disappeared. I guess it just needed to stretch the plastic a bit.  This is a great product.

title: On the Go with the Blue Bottle text: The RefreshH2Gp Sleek Filter Bottle is one of those creations that is hard to dispute. How long have some "must hydrate" individuals been denied easy, affordable way to keep the body at the full mark with clean water? Long enough, I am sure, but with this bottle, any one on the go, can now replenish liquids in the most unlikely places, knowing that they are safely consuming clean water wherever their path has led. People that have very little chance of drinking safe water can now safeguard that very important aspect by having access to a product such as this one.
Found out that to make it a little better the first time one takes a life giving swallow, is is best to let the filter rest in water for a couple of hours, then dispense properly (thirsty soil, indoor plant, etc.), and get ready to enjoy water from the faucet that did not need to be boiled to drink after, and perhaps a few cubes of ice to go with that? Just by the innovation alone, however simple the idea might seem now, it gets high marks for it works to allow anyone to drink better water for a change. Amazon, can not say enough so I will just say thanks for delivering this rather efficient blue color filter bottle right before summer, which seems to be the perfect season for water drinking, not to disrespect Winter, Fall and Spring, of course when it comes to proper hydration. Taste okey do key, which is another word for so so, but knowing it is filtered, but it would be wise to have extra filters handy as their life expectancies is about a month. Either way, is a simple, above average product. 4.5 Stars.

title: Trouble staying at fixed height, anti-shock broke first use text: I have trekking poles in my car and at my residence, I wanted a second set at my mothers house for when I'm visiting and want to go hiking near a lake. I thought a cheaper set would work as I am hardly ever here. These are the worst set of poles I have ever seen. I have given poles as gifts and was happy this pair was not one such set or I would have been embarrassed.
I had set the poles at home, to my desired length. At the lake, before I could even take a step, one kept collapsing at the bottom. I did not trek of road, due to this. I fixed the poles again and hoped they would stay but the bottom of the pole seems very flimsy. I decided to walk to road around the lake....cautiously, I have had a double knee replacement so I rely on the poles a bit more than I used to. The pole stayed fixed to my adjustment but the shock nechanism broke in one of the handles.
I have them and as I'm seldom at my mothers, and do not have the time to mess around with sending them back, I will keep them but I cannot recommend them at all and I am baffled by the high rating.
I know walking and trekking poles and these are awful. I guess you get what you pay for.
If you have had injuries to your knees I absolutely would not rely on them.
I was hoping to write a better review as I wanted to like them (though not being my primary poles my standard were low to begin with so I ordered the cheap set) but they are awful.

Absolutely do not recommend these at all!

title: Excellent value
text: I'd be disappointed if this table were used in a tournament (I can hear the difference), but it's an excellent casual table. Delivery went smoothly and the XPO folks opened the box so I could inspect for damage. Assembly went pretty smoothly. The nuts were somewhat hard to hold in place while screwing the bolts since they had a plastic gastket. I used two wrenches---one to hold the nut and one to screw-in the bolt. One of the holes was slightly misaligned, but  loosening and adjusting allowed the bolt to go in easily. Standing up the table after assembly was slightly tricky. I did it by myself and found that if I put it on the side, I was able to stand it upright w/o help. Changing the table from vertical to horizontal requires that I pull the legs out slightly, else they get stuck trying to go the wrong direction. The table top had a few small blemishes, but nothing that affects play. The wheels roll well, but don't always swivel easily; but, a bit of pushing in the right spot gets them moving. Overall, the play is great and it's pretty easy to convert from full table to single-player practice. Net is high-quality and is easy to tighten. Would purchase again.

title: A must for those who want to stay hydrated text: This is a very nice, clear water bottle. It can hold up to 64oz of water or the liquid of your choice really. On the side it has some motivational time markers to keep you on track for your water / fluid intake. This should keep you nicely hydrated every day, if you can empty this every day. I admit drinking that much water is quite a bit and I personally prefer mine flavored in some way, either making tea out of it or something else really.

It has a wide opening which allows you to quickly fill it as well as add ice to it if you choose to. That also makes it easier to clean it. It has a flip top that has a secure lock so you can protect the opening you are drinking from, from dust, dirt, germs or whatever else really. You can use the straw it comes with or just remove it, totally up to you, personally I prefer to use it without it. It has a nice carrying handle that makes it easy to lug it along with you.

It is BPA and toxin free which is important since you don't want to add toxins to your body slowly but surely through your water, trust me you will add it plenty of other ways, you don't have to add this one. This bottle comes in plenty of fun designs but also some muted single colors as well, so plenty for everyone to choose from.

title: Tortuga: keeping it together and staying cool! text: Whether you're picnicking at the park, glamping for a day in the mountains, or hanging out at the beach, this cooler tote combo will help make enjoying your small getaway a lot easier. This would also do really well for those trips to the grocery store.

Pros:
-LARGE cooler compartment for beverages, fruits, and meats before they hit the grill.
-LARGE tote compartment for the room temp essentials, whether they be your picnic plates and utensils, beach towels, other snacks,etc.
-Very thick insulation, stuff stays cool as long as you don't let the cool out too much!
-Secure your stuff in the tote using the drawstring with the slide toggle
-Really liked the easy to grip large loopy handles to extend and help grip the zipper for the main compartment and the pocket in the tote: comes in handy for when your fingers are wet or if you have a hard time gripping those small zipper pullers.
-Pocket in the tote is a genius idea to keep your small valuables from falling in between all your goodies or falling out of the tote completely...don't lose your stuff, zip them up in that pocket!
-A little bit more storage available in the mesh pocket for your books, other small/flat things you'd want to take with you on your outing
-Mesh material makes it easy to clear out any sand or small crumbs in the tote and mesh pocket areas

Wishlist:
-more color options
-adjustable shoulder strap
-flat bottom removable insert to keep the bottom of the cooler and tote flat

Suggestions for use:
-Pack frozen bottles of water to stick in the cooler instead of cubes of ice, that way you get the cooler effect with less mess and you get a nice cold water to drink in the end!
-Use a caribiner to hang other accessories (not too heavy) on the built-in fancy metal eye bolt anchor on the side of the cooler...be careful of over packing too much stuff though!

title: Well made, worth the price. text: I ordered the CoC #1

Probably the best grip trainer I've owned, very durable, high quality materials. As others have said, the texture on it is a bit rough at first, but that's just a matter of building up the callouses, or you can wrap it in athletic tape instead.

As for grip difficulty: I ordered the #1, which has a 140lb pull, and found that I can't close it all the way, there is about 1/2" (13mm) gap. I'm pretty strong, but not really a lifter or anything. For reference, I had a pair of inexpensive grippers like these: [[ASIN:B0006GCBL4 Gripmaster 14003-BLK Hand Exerciser Black, Heavy Tension (9-Pounds per Finger)]] and could do sets of 100+ easily, and a set of those cheap grippers with the contoured, black plastic handles and chrome coil on top, and could do sets of sixty or seventy on those. I'm going to keep the #1, but I'm also ordering a CoC Trainer, which has a 100lb pull, so I can work up to it. That's what I'd recommend for anyone who is fit but just starting grip training in earnest.

EDIT: Okay, so I ordered the Training model and used that for a few weeks. I could close that one with some effort, and quickly built my way up to sets of twelve. Now I can do sets of about three on the #1. Once I can hit sets of about twenty on this one, I'll move up.

title: About as easy and effective as you could ask for text: I use this foam in a Pelican case which holds sensitive electronic equipment, the sort which is rectangular in size. I've tried many other kinds of foam - stiffer foam which doesn't yield easily, softer foam which does, but nothing beats the cubes for usability. I used razors, art knives, rulers and extreme care, but it in the end the shapes always came out ragged, rough, and far from square. I doubt I could manage a really clean job without an actual laser cutter.

This bypassed the need for all of that. Basically, the foam pad comes pre-cut, except for a very thin layer of foam in the very middle of the pad. It is a simple matter to pluck out the cubes - really, the little square columns of foam - in the approximate shape of what you want to store in the case. I haven't had any issues with too many cubes coming out at once, if you use even the slightest care, you can be sure that you are removing only exactly what you need to. Each column is about 1/4" square I believe.

The set comes with an undulating top insert, and a solid bottom insert, as well as two pluckable cube inserts for the middle.

I would definitely recommend this as the replacement foam for the Pelican case over alternatives. It might not be as good as inserts which have been custom-shaped to components, but it is about as close as you can get.

title: It works!
text: This thing will edge your skis and your board, but its more of a quick tune tool to get out burrs and remove rust before the start of ski season. I live on the east coast (read: ice coast) so its imperative to have sharp edges if youre skiing anything other than park. Actually even in the park. Now as far as these types of tools go, it works. Its nothing special. It doesn't change the bevel of your ski and just does a standard edge. Definitely takes a bit of pressure and a few good strokes to get the edge sharpened well, but it will get the job done and doesn't mess with your base! I did notice that if youre not really careful, it can slip off the metal edge and then you'll be running your hand down the freshly sharpened edge instead, so might be a good idea to wear some protective gloves just in case! I used it before a ski day at blue mountain and my edges held up even on the icier runs at night, so it def works!

title: Keeps my tea hot!

This has been a great addition because it goes into my "tea" category. I usually sip for several hours on a cup of tea (hot) and this keeps it hot long enough to still be drinkable when I get to the bottom, as well as preventing leaks (yes it's been knocked over before) which makes it a winner for me! title: Strong, perfect size, no problems ... text: I got these to replace the zipper pulls on a pair of zippered compression knee-highs. The original pulls were plastic "snap-on" type, and they pulled out the first time I tried to use them. Saw these, and took a chance.

VERY happy I did! These are the perfect size, very strong, and work perfectly. If you've never worn compression stockings, you may not realize how strong the compression is. These socks were rated at 40-50mmHg compression, so one of the highest ratings. That means that it takes a LOT of effort/force to get the zipper up, and for someone like me (not young, not lithe, not flexible, not skinny) having some sort of help is necessary. With these, I can use one hand to hold the two sides of the zipper together, and use the pull to work the zipper up. The textured pull is non-slip, so even if my hands are a little damp, these are fine. Whew! These helped make what could have been a two-person job into a one-person effort, and I'm able to don the socks in less than 10 minutes.

The cord is surprisingly strong, and so far, I've had no issues at all with the textured plastic "pull" part popping off. I've used the same pair of these on the socks daily for the past 3 weeks, and they show no signs of wear or durability issues. (Photo included ... )

Highly recommended!

title: Best tent i have ever seen! text: I bought this tent for my husband and I. We wanted something that was roomy, easy to put up, and have the straight sides so could stand up.
This tent definitely hit all those marks but what I have to say I am most impressed with and why I am writing this review today is how well it stood up to the Rain. We've been using the tent all summer. we camp at the beach quite often or in the mountains and it has gotten hit with a few light rain showers, handled it great! but last weekend we got caught in a very severe thunder and lightning storm that dumped about an inch of rain in just over an hour. That tent kept us dry! The only place we had a problem was going in and out the door because it was raining so hard. There was no sweating it did not seep through the floor no trickling down the walls on the inside of the tent... I was seriously amazed.
And the setup and takedown is so incredibly fast and easy I have arthritis and I can do it by myself you can do it in less than 2 minutes with someone else.

title: Amazing improvement! text: Two months ago, I had a custom saddle built on an existing 50 year old mesquite tree. (I found the tree in Mexico in perfect condition) This has been an amazing process and the saddle is 90% perfect. My issue was the new stirrups and leather fenders....so stiff and that equates to knee and ankle pain trying to break everything in over time.

These stirrup turners were EXACTLY what I needed. Holy cow! Immediate comfort and correct placement. They do add length so you definitely need to adjust your stirrups. I ended up going up three holes for proper leg placement after adding these. Fortunately, my saddle maker measured my short legs and added extra holes to compensate.

The addition of these turners means I can mount safely from anywhere and instantly find my right stirrup without looking. The stirrups stay in the correct angle and are balanced even on rough, steep mountain trails. That's a big deal out in the Big Bend desert mountains of West Texas. Installation was quite simple and took just a few minutes. My only complaint is because these are so thick and stiff (they have to be) my ankles can take a beating after several hours on the trails. Even in tall boots. I've begun wrapping them in vet wrap just to add a bit of cushion and that has helped significantly. I'm coming in from hard, long rides without limping anymore because my stirrup placement is finally set up correctly.

title: For what it is, I like it ... text: I debated giving this 3 stars instead of 4, but for its intended use (primarily camping), it works nicely.

It couldn't be easier to prepare: add a cup of boiling water, stir, seal pouch, and wait 5-6 minutes (you can also open the pouch after 3 minutes, stir, then reseal wait another 2-3 minutes). Drain off excess water (I snipped a corner of the pouch about 1/4" to create a drain). Then eat right out of the bag if you want. It's the lack of having to have pots/pans/plates/etc that makes this interesting, I think. And more expensive.

It's only a good buy if it tastes good, and this tastes ... OK. It's not like home-cooked eggs and bacon. The texture is sort of spongy, and the bacon bits are more jerky like than crispy bacon. But the flavors are quite good. Not overly salty, tastes like eggs.

The primary positives for this are the ease of packing for a hiking/camping adventure. The packages weigh very little, and don't require you to pack other items normally needed for cooking/eating except a few forks/spoons, and a cup that can be used for measuring. What's left when you're finished is a very light-weight pouch, again easily packed for disposal later.

This IS pricey, though -- you're paying for the convenience of having a complete meal, including "cooking" and "serving," self-contained in one easy-to-pack-and-dispose-of pouch.

If you have the luxury of cooking equipment, there are tastier alternatives (I'm partial to the OvaEasy eggs -- great taste/texture, decent price). But if you really need to "pack light," this is a very good option for a tasty breakfast.

title: Great for outdoor event, employment or activity! text: Ordered for daughter who works varied shifts as a hotel valet.. and weather gets chilly working early mornings + late at night! This heat source has offered a solution when standing outside in the cold! The massage option is really just a frill on top!! (think continued phone vibration- and note: can be used with heat only!) Light source adds safety perk with ability to use walking in the dark..

Equipped with x3 varied heat levels.. I find its really just high or low- nothing real distinct in between but, its all you’ll need! LED let’s you easily see heat and battery level. If charged overnite with included usb it lasts all day..!!

Worked best tucked into a pant pocket and cup hands around it as needed to kick up heat.. so when not “holding” heat it can penetrate thru clothing layer giving a nice “hot-shot!” Could also tuck into jacket pocket and slip hands in as needed. Not realistic in gloves bc of size and if it does fit.. hand use is obsolete bc of its interference.

A solution for added heat on a repeated bases.. a little bit of warm can go a long way! Great for outdoor work, activity, sport venue, etc.. any scenario involving cooler weather. Hoping info helps your decision- stay safe everyone.
