title: Sturdy, roomy day pack text: My husband was looking for a day pack. I bought him 6 backpacks to compare. The [[ASIN:B010LAU5CG Hiking Cycling Backpack, Sunhiker Sports Outdoor Backpack Bag Running Camping Backpack Water Resistant Lightweight SMALL Daypack 25L M441 (Black)]], the [[ASIN:B00DNTR5CQ Osprey Packs Momentum 22 Daypack (Spring 2016 Model), Carbide Grey]], the [[ASIN:B014EMLHDI Outlander Packable Handy Lightweight Travel Hiking Backpack Daypack, Grey]], the [[ASIN:B00FUWSTI8 Lightweight Rucksack 25L for men women kids - Foldable into Inner pocket (BLACK)]], the [[ASIN:B013K7CJD0 Cycling Hiking Backpack Sunhiker Water Resistant Travel Backpack Lightweight SMALL Daypack M0714 (Dark Green)]], and the [[ASIN:B01EH0YGSU Free Knight 25L Packable Handy Lightweight Travel Backpack Daypack-Lifetime Warranty (New Grey)]]. There were pros and cons for each pack. He decided to keep the [[ASIN:B010LAU5CG Hiking Cycling Backpack, Sunhiker Sports Outdoor Backpack Bag Running Camping Backpack Water Resistant Lightweight SMALL Daypack 25L M441 (Black)]]because it met his needs the best. We ordered all packs in gray, green, or black. We returned the other 5 packs. I liked 2 of the lightweight foldable packs - the [[ASIN:B014EMLHDI Outlander Packable Handy Lightweight Travel Hiking Backpack Daypack, Grey]]and the [[ASIN:B01EH0YGSU Free Knight 25L Packable Handy Lightweight Travel Backpack Daypack-Lifetime Warranty (New Grey)]]. I decided to order those for myself in Pink and Purple.
All of the packs had a mesh pocket on each side of the pack for water bottles. We tested them all with a Nalgene bottle and a bottle of water. All of the packs could easily hold the bottle of water. Some were a very tight fit for the Nalgene bottles. All packs had a main compartment with one or two pockets in the front of the pack. The main compartments varied from 561 cubic inches to 1386 cubic inches. 3 of the packs were lightweight, foldable, and storable in their own pocket.
Here are my summaries of this pack:
1386 cubic inches
18” x 11” x 7”
7” extra large mesh pockets
Bottle holder covers about 6” of the bottle
Straps 2 1/2” wide
Waist strap extends to about 45”
Small pockets on each side of the waist strap. Sized to fit a set of keys. 4” x 3” x 1”
Pros:
- Fabric felt very durable
- Pack was very sturdy and kept it’s shape due to back support panel
- Thick padding on back of pack
- Easy to adjust chest strap – up and down as well as tighten and loosen
- Whistle on chest strap buckle
- Adjustable waist strap
- Handle at top of pack for an additional way of carrying it
- Easy to adjust shoulder straps
- Shoulder straps were very padded and comfortable
- Side pockets are extra large mesh reinforced with fabric at sides and bottom
- 2 zippered front compartments
- Extra side support straps
- 4 extra loops on outside of pack. 2 at bottom. 2 towards the top
- One large pocket inside the main compartment. Useful for notebook or laptop
Cons:
- None really
- Heavier pack than foldable packs

This was a sturdy, roomy day pack, so my husband kept it.

Update: June 2017. My husband uses this daily for work. It has held up very well except for the design on the front peeling almost immediately. He's still happy with this purchase despite the cosmetic issue. He said it's a great size and a great price for carrying his notebook laptop and things to/from work. I will post a pic.

title: surprisingly comfortable for a stool, nice bag-cooler-stool combo. Good details, worth the try text: Worth the try. I hope it holds up, and I will update if I experience anything regarding that.

I bought two, one for myself and one for my husband. We are heavy folks, and this is rated to 330 lbs (some color options are rated to 400 lbs). This in not person weight only, but it also takes in force of sitting down, as well as gear in the bag and on person.

I like the variety of colors, the generous shoulder straps, the fairly comfortable bench seat (really quite nice for something that is part of a bag), the reflective strip, the spacious cooler, the zip pocket, water bottle holder, and the fact that the frame is nonobtrusive. It does not feel awkward at all to walk with this on as a backpack. Take note of the legs. Had this been a four-corner leg frame (like a chair), then the weight would likely push them into the ground. Instead, these are rounded and in one full piece, so the weight is distributed more evenly. Feel light, not at all heavy. Good detail.

Funny thing, we actually have four of these. As mentioned, I bought one for my husband and myself. At the time, they are $25 each, and I thought that was a good price to take a chance with. And at the same time, my husband bought one for himself and for me. He made a point to add on some paracord zipper pulls. All together we have 3 camo packs, and one army green. He had already used his several times for hunting with no complaints. Not really sure if he used it as a bag or cooler, but he definitely used it as a stool. I haven't used mine yet other than to try it on. I will be keeping it in my car. I tend to go for hikes, and I like the option of having a bag-stool-cooler combo. Also, I like to have extra stuff in my car for emergencies and such. Also works nice for impromptu outdoor gatherings at friends houses. Got myself a seat no matter where I go. I'm a 2 is 1, 1 is none sort of thinker, so I plan to hold onto my 2nd one incase one breaks down or I simply want to use something other than camo (I have a camo one and a green one for myself).

title: Capturing nature. 4.5 stars
text: My backyard is full of wildlife – rabbits, birds (i.e., hummingbirds, cardinals, chickadees, hawks) squirrels, and chipmunks, so the Zimoce Trail Camera seemed like the perfect gadget to have. It allows me to get some great photographs of the wildlife that seems to elude me when I am out there. This camera is small and compact, about the size of a small garden “brick” or a little bigger than my hand. It can be mounted with a strap or by a bracket, that can be screwed into a post or tree. This camera is easy to set up, simply add 12 AA batteries (not included) and you are good to go. It works on motion, so once the photo(s) are taken, you can view them on the monitor/display or connect the camera to your television or computer. My only criticism is that it snaps photos if it rains or is windy, not just when wildlife triggers it. I had 300 plus photos of basically nothing within a couple of hours, but at least those pictures it did capture were clear. This camera also has the ability to record HD quality video(s), which will probably appeal to hunters or game enthusiast. The quality of both the pictures and videos are decent. In conclusion, I would give this camera 4.5 stars. It is easy to set up and use, while capturing shots of my wildlife. I’d recommend it.

title: High quality, soft and warm fleece PJs but runs larger than expected text: I ordered this for my cat Jake because putting on PJs or a shirt before bed is the only thing that keeps him quiet throughout the night. I always purchase a size small for him because an XS is usually too small. However, these are huge as can be seen from the last three photos. He is about 10 pounds and has a 12-13" back. Therefore, an XXS or P would have probably fit him but not this small which is rated for a whippet or dog with an 18" back.

I only took off one point for the sizing because had I seen the size chart I would have known it would not have fit. However, the size chart on the Amazon site differs a bit from the sizing listed on the packaging. For example, according to the size chart on the packaging, a whippet can take between a S and M but on the Amazon site it says a small.

Nevertheless, this is a wonderful set of PJ's for indoor or outdoor wear. They feel high quality, are warm, and made of soft fleece. It has a detachable hood that is affixed in place via snaps. There is a hole at the center of the neckline (under the collar) for a leash to pass through. There are jersey cuffs around all four paws to keep the leggings in place. Overall, this is a wonderful "coat" that is machine washable (but hang dry) and is reasonably priced at the current price of $19.21. Just be very careful of the sizing. The first photo shows the size chart on the packaging but there is also reasonable sizing recommendations on the Amazon site even if they do not match exactly with the packaging photo.

title: COLOR BLEEDS; just barely works as foot bath; best for outdoors or repurpose as ice bucket text: I have another one of [[ASIN:B091GF5B46 these]] type foot baths and fell in love with it so much that I wanted another one.

In the package is one carry pouch and one very small outdoor foot bath. The basin is fully collapsible and very small.  I unfolded it completely and made sure the edge of the basin was standing up.

As can be seen by my photos, I actually used this indoors and it worked. I had to be careful not to let water flow over the edge. This is really for outdoor use only. To ensure the water stays inside, I only filled it several inches, enough to soak up to the base of my ankles.

Once I was done, I rinsed the bath out. There was a water spot on my floor because the bottom of the basin gets wet when in the sink--another reason this should be used outdoors. Note that it takes many hours for this basin to dry. 

I was actually going to rate this 4 stars like I did my other one because it operates exactly the same. However, the purple color of this bath bled all over my towels and I could not rinse the color out. It destroyed my towels.

In summary, this foot bath is portable and does work as long as one is careful. However, this can be repurposed as an ice bucket with drinks for a picnic or to hold small beach toys for the kids. At the current price of $7.99, this is more expensive than the one I already own. It is not great but does somewhat serve the purpose it was intended for. What I love about this is that I do not have to carry a heavy pail to bathe my feet. Also, it folds down nicely. This would have received 4 stars from me if it were not for the color bleed. I cannot recommend this due to that issue and my recommendation would be to purchase this [[ASIN:B091GF5B46 one]] instead. Not only is that one cheaper but there is no color bleed.

UPDATE: I washed the towels twice that this bucket bled on and the color DID NOT come out. This is such a BIG NEGATIVE. Even if using this outdoors, the color will bleed all over--one's clothes, the camper floor, the towels, etc.

title: Works For Long Walks For Me text: When I don't get the chance to get exercise for a while, I have a tendency to push right in and go for extensively long walks up hills and such. In other words I overdo it a bit. Then I can get some sore legs. Let's see how these worked out.

WHAT ARE THESE LIKE?
These compression sleeves come in a plastic bag. They slip on the legs and go from below the need to just above the ankle. I should not say they SLIP on, because it is a bit of tug of war, but they do seem to fit well on me. I would compare these to the tops of basketball or sports socks that are very firm and tight. They are nylon and are thinner than some compression sleeves I have used in the past, but for summer that is actually a good thing.

COLOR
These are a pretty mint green in color with dark grey stripes on them.

CALF SIZE
My calf size is about 15 inches or a bit more depending on the day. These fit me well and did not make me get into pain or anything. The pair I am talking about are a size L.

SHIN SPLINTS
I have had some shin splint issues, and these do help with that kind of pain. They are especially good if you want to put some hot rub on the legs in between icing them down for shin splints. There is sine relief wearing these if they are not too tight.

THE BOTTOM LINE
For support in walking or in treating shin splints, these are pretty nice. There is a certain amount of tugging to get them on which could be difficult if you are dealing with back issues, but all in all they are pretty nice and perform well.

MY RATING
FOUR STARS. They are nice and I like them. I am not WOWed but they are solid performers. They are a bit thin for long term use, in my opinion.

text: I have a few of these inflatable pillows and these aren't terrible but they're not the best by any means.  It's nice that they come as a pair however they do not stay in place at all for me. title: Best water bottle I have tried text: I have been using these for a few months now and it is my favorite beverage bottle. I love every feature:

title: Good mesh bag for the beach text: Overall, a good bag for going to the beach, gym, or park. Ideal for light loads. If participating in water activities, I'd recommend packing large trash bags with you for keeping things dry if needed (the whole bag or just some of the bag's contents).

Pros:
-Pretty spacious considering it's design! It fits my split fins, mask box, snorkel, dive boot bag, and towel chamois container with plenty of space to spare for beach towels, dry clothes, or snacks
-It comes with a carabiner which I've attached to my dive boot bag and plan on attaching it to the strap when walking around so I can fit more things in the main compartment.
-Zipper is big and easy to open and close.
-Strap appears to be well sewn into the mesh material
-Mesh material looks sturdy, just be careful not to run into something and rip it
-Mesh material is good for having to carry wet or damp things, and sand can escape so you don't take them home with you.
-Good price

Cons:
- Bottom of bag is straight stitched (imagine fold the shorter side of the rectangular mesh material in half and stitch one edge together) and not round (round mesh material stitched to the shorter side of the rectangle to make a cylindrical shaped bag). Could have more space and better over all shape if it was cylindrical.
-Single flat pocket with no pleat fold to allow more storage space (think military cargo pants' pockets). Can insert small flat things in there with no problem unless the bag itself is pretty full then getting your hand in there to get something out will require rearranging the contents of the bag a bit.
-Only one strap with fixed length, not long enough to go across your chest nor is it padded.
-Strap could use a few more inches to give space for shoulder and bag bulk. You might have to rearrange or consider placement of things during packing so your stuff isn't digging into your back whilst carrying your bag to your destination.

title: Great indoor fun - survived doubles with dogs! Easy to put out & away text: Clean adult indoor fun!! After five days of nonstop rain, cold and wind, I gave up and put this badminton set together in our great room between the windows and the fireplace. My husband was highly amused when I announced we had hot toddies, a roaring fire AND badminton awaiting us on the "lido deck". The dogs perked right up and played with us - turns out, dogs are very handy for retrieving shuttle cocks from under recliners and end tables and hounds love to leap up to snatch the birdie midair as well, which makes keeping score impossible, what with the being doubled over laughing and arguing about which dog's mouth constitutes in or out of bounds.

Bottom line - this was very easy to set up for one person, the racquets are nicely balanced and seem sturdy, the self supporting case/base survived five large Rhodesian Ridgeback dogs racing over and around it while we played, the poles survived being bashed into by the dogs and the two shuttle cocks flew well and even took a chewing without falling apart. This set probably isn't large enough for four adults, but two adults and two kids could play together just fine. My only issue was breaking it down - one off the poles didn't want to telescope properly on the first try, but I am not blaming the equipment since that may very well have been the result of our canine foolishness.

title: Best I have ever used. Has many other uses. text: I like how compact everything nicely fits into a very durable case. All of the accessories are quality made. I have used gun cleaning kits from many other manufacturers for cleaning engines and restoration cleaning of antiques. This one I can tell it will last it might be slower in ways compared to other methods yet it is gentle and really does an amazing job. Pulling the debris away from all of the areas that you do not want debris to be is critical for the life of everything from a firearm to an engine or anything else that requires the use of a cleaning kit like this. When you are finished using the kit clean everything up, put it away and you should have a tool kit that will last a long time. This is not a disposable or junk kit it is built to last just dont force it use common sense read instructions. I highly recommend this kit for anyone who is learning about firearms because it is simple to use. Used as the instructions say your not going to harm your investment you will protect it along with learning more about your firearms or whatever else you are cleaning. Give one of these a try you might like it. I know that I am very pleased with my purchase. Thank you.

P.S. if you like a bore snake I think you would be extremely happy with one of these kits it does a much better job.

title: Water bottle
text: This water bottle speaker was easy to connect (used an iphone XR) and the speak is very loud... loud enough for music at a small gathering of 5-8 people. The charging cord comes with the bottle. The speaker is in the lid and has a bluetooth button on it and the port for charging. There is obviously a layer in between the water and the speaker so the speaker is protected. It is matte black with silver trimming. The texture of the bottle keeps it from producing sweat and helps it to stay dry. The real test was whether water actually stays cold for 24 hours and it does! I put cold water in it at 4:20pm yesterday and left the bottle on my desk in my room that keeps a normal temparature. The water was still cold at 8:37pm, by 11:24pm it was still cold, but I could notice a little difference. I checked it again at 7:15am, 12pm, and 3pm and it was still cold. It wasn't freezing cold like when I originally put it in, but cold enough and better than a normal water bottle or container that doesn't provide this feature. By 4pm the water was semi-warm, still not completely warm. So, I would recommend this water bottle.

title: Throws nice but would be nice to have instructions on the add-a-gram
text: This is a nice set of darts. It comes with 3 darts that each have a 2 gram barrel. The grips are nickel plated. The shafts are aluminum. The flights are a nice sparkling purple, silver and black coloration. You also get a second set that is black, white, grey with red Viper lettering. You also get add-a-grams, additional soft tips, nylon shafts, flight protectors and a wrench. There are no instructions. None of the add-a-grams have a weight listing. I even checked on the website and no instructions there either. I did find some information that indicates you would have to weight the entire put together dart to get the weight. Then if you want it more or less, you would need to swap out the barrel tip and weigh again. I noticed that the add a grams that are included have different lengths of the screw in and that might be the key!

title: All Metal and Just Right
text: I wanted metal mirrors without plastic for a vintage bicycle.  I read good reviews of these mirrors and ordered them.  They look very similar to older motorcycle mirrors.  They attach with the same kind of cast alloy clamps on the handlebars.  The mirrors have just the right amount of convex curve.  I had purchased another bike mirror that is too convex and makes everything look tiny and too small to see.  These mirrors are big and they don't shrink objects excessively, but still have a wide angle view.  I'm not sure the right-side mirror is useful on a bicycle.  I just don't merge right often enough to really justify having on there.  Unfortunately, I can't flip it and use it as a left mirror on another bike.  I'm thinking of ordering another set of these to get another left mirror.

title: A Great rod for on the go!! text: This fishing rod was purchased for my husband who loves fishing and boating. He loves it. The fact that he can just fold it and store it easily in his truck and have it with him all the time. He says it works well with his spinning reel and has caught several fish on it and it handled them well. Due to the collapsible feature he's not so certain that it would handle a 5 or 6 pound bass but he'd love to hook up with one just to see how it would do. Overall, he likes it and would , and has, suggested to a few friends that they look into it. The expandable rod opens in 8 different places making it a 7'6" total length. The eyelets and connectors are metal and strong . The rod does collapse down with ease. The handle is a soft suede material making for a good grip.
The rod does come with a locking cap at the end and a storage bag.
I received this product at a discount for my honest and unbiased review.

title: Study material, roomy, quality made! (•‿•) text: Having good quality and attractive yoga gear is essential. This black bag that i have is just that.... made very well. The material is a rugged, sturdy canvas and available in several colors. This is a nice bag, the stitching is done well and holds great. Also, the zippers flow easily. It is also important that the mesh pockets hold up too, as one tends to stick sharp objects into it. These pockets are not flimsy.

On the inside of the bag is a coating that allows for moisture resistance, and easy wipe if needed. You also have the holes for venting, in case you leave clothes in their for long. I always wipe my mat before putting it back. But if you get the inside dirty, it is easy to clean.

Carrying this is easy. I can adjust the strap, fill the bag with my yoga mat, or my regular gym mat. There is enough room in this bag for your yoga mat, even if your mat is slightly thicker than normal. My gym mat is slightly thicker than a regular yoga mat, and it fits easily. I like the pockets and especially the outside pocket....

So, with mesh pockets, a handy outside pocket, zippers that flow easily, study carrying strap and rugged material, this is excellent. Yoga bag for review. ..... Rizzo (•‿•)

title: PERFECT AIR COMPRESSOR for BICYCLISTS! text: I love riding my recumbent trike and tend to ride long distances when I ride. As other riders understand you have to be prepared for all sorts of emergency circumstances.

My trike has a bag attached to the back of the seat where I’m able to carry my emergency supplies. I have my multi tools, a patch kit, a few essentials and this pump.

I have needed this pump on a few occasions and it has never let me down. While it is small, it is powerful. It’s important to check it monthly to make sure it’s charged but other than that this has proven to be a reliable pump that I know I can depend on when I need it.

If you are looking for a dependable pump that requires little space and can go anywhere - this is the product you need.

title: Great scooter, but ours came with a major flaw. text: There are a lot of great things about this scooter, with one significant bad (which I think was a fluke in our case, but definitely affected my opinion).
Good: the colors and graphics are cute, but not too childish or annoying. The textured base is perfect for keeping your child's riding foot in place. The size is just right, and I love that it will adjust as my granddaughter grows. She's really excited about it, and has had fun learning how to use it.
BAD: one of the handle tubes was too big for where it needed to be inserted into the frame. The whole scooter comes assembled, but broken down - you flip a lever to raise the long frame from the base, and you pull the handles out of an attached clip and then insert them into the metal tube (there is a photo on the product page of the collapsed scooter). I was totally confused, but checked and double-checked - one of the handles was both bigger than the other handle, and just too big too fit. SO...we had to laboriously file down the metal on the handle and the tube in order to even make it work. Even so, we didn't get it filed down enough to pull it back out (wrenching into place was really tough), so that side won't be able to collapse now. I do like the scooter, but when you need to fix a manufacturing flaw to get something to work, it's disappointing.

title: A Solid Thermos Bottle With Some Minor Issues text: The bottle seems well made, solid and durable enough for rugged use. The matte black look of mine is stylish and appealing though it has picked up some scuff marks in just a few days of light use. About the issues I mentioned in the headline, one is that the bottle gets slippery when wet, with an almost slimy feel to it. Another issue is the standard size of the mouth. I wish it was a bit bigger. As an old guy, my hands are a bit shaky. Although I haven't done it yet, every time I pour hot coffee into this bottle, I'm afraid that I'm going to splash some on my hands.

That hot coffee raises another point about this bottle. If you keep the lid on to keep the beverage hot, every time you do take a drink, it's going to be hot. I had never thought of it before but that's why those old Stanley thermos bottles came with their own cup. You could pour some of your hot coffee into the cup so it could cool to drinking temperature while leaving the rest in the thermos to stay hot. With this bottle you need a separate cup. That's a minor issue to be sure but one worth noting if you plan on using it to carry hot liquids to work or on an extended hike.

title: This Lantern Came In Really Handy
text: In general, our family really likes the multi-functional camping lanterns. That's the ones like this which can be used as a flashlight when walking, an area light when camping, or an emergency flasher when needed. We try to keep several such lanterns on hand for both camping and emergency use. This particular lantern was unexpectedly helpful in another scenario. One of Mom's sisters broke her ankle and was laid up in bed for a while. She couldn't get up to turn the room light off and on, so Mom loaned her this lantern. Kept on a bedside stand, it was easily accessible and more than bright enough for our invalid's needs. The sturdy rubber handle and the two metal hangers on top, which fold out of the way when not needed, will come in handy for actual camping. This lantern can also serve as a power bank for smartphones, which our invalid also very much liked. All in all, our family was very happy to have this lantern on hand when it was needed and we gratefully give it a full 5 star rating.

title: Seems really solid. text: I only have one ride in with this BB so far, but already I can tell it's a night-and-day improvement over the vintage BB it replaces.

I tooled up to overhaul the old BB on a ca. 1990 Trek, and that went well except for the condition of the spindle; it had already become pitted from foreign objects grinding around in there.

The new UN55 is butter smooth and feels more solid, too.

My only reservation is the spacing. I measured slightly under 113mm on the old spindle, so figured the 113mm UN55 would be the tiniest bit wide. In fact it was a tiny bit narrow, as the chainrings lined up slightly to the left of where they were. I adjusted the limit screw and tension on the front derailleur and the bike seems to work fine now. Not sure whether I should try a wider BB or what; I'm new to proper road bike mechanics. Also I didn't actually measure the new spindle to verify that it really is 113mm; I only noticed the discrepancy after I assembled the whole thing and I didn't want to back out all the parts just to measure....

My UN55 was shipped from Bell's Bike Shop and it was missing the bolts. I had to go to a local store and get a couple of spare bolts from their parts bin.

title: Outdoor Fun!
text: We enjoy outdoor games like this bean bag toss. This one was easy to put together, but the legs had to be forced into position because they were at a different angle. Once in position, they fall out if you pick the whole thing up. My husband said can permanently screw them into place, but then we would lose the "easy to transport" feature. It wouldn't be too complicated to move them, they just wouldn't pack flat. The bean bags are filled with bean type filler but there's also something in there that crinkles a lot and reminds me of a cat toy. There were a lot of loose threads on the bags, but they seem to be made well. The instructions tell you how to play the game, but we couldn't find anything about the scoring other than the winner is the first person to get to 21 without going over. In reading other reviews, I figured out that it's 3 points for the top hole, 2 for the middle one and 1 for the lower one. Overall, it is a fun game. I like the patriotic look to it so it is perfect for summer gatherings.

title: Great set of brushes for cleaning kits text: If you have one or several hydration packs, then you know that eventually they accumulate biofilm of one kind or another, or the slimy or blackish variety, usually in some hard-to-reach corner. You also know that you can either try to improvise some sort of ram-rod setup with a dowel and paper towel, or soak the whole setup in a 1:4 bleach water mix and dissolve any living organisms that way, permanently enchanting the pack with the smell and taste of pool water.

This kit avoids that by giving you specific tools to scrub out the little tubes and the pack itself. I've tested it and found it to be very effective - I was able to get right down into all the corners with a decent scubbing, and then fill the bladder with a water and a few drops of chlorine bleach to kill off any remaining contaminants. It was much easier than any previous attempts I've made at cleaning. I can't speak to the effectiveness of the plastic drying rack - many of my hydration packs are old and only have 1" diameter mouth at one end - but the rest of the tools make this kit worth buying, in my opinion.

Would recommend.

title: Way better than bungee cords
text: I wish I would have known about these earlier. They work really well! There is very little stretch, so when you tighten the strap, the wheel stays secure. The Velcro is more than strong enough to keep it in place. I’ve used bungee cords for years, and I would have to stretch them tight so the front wheel wouldn’t sway. Sometimes that required creative routing of the bungee. And I’ve broken a few bungee cords, which fortunately didn’t cause any damage or injuries.  But those risks are gone with these straps. They are plenty long to strap the front wheel to the down tube, even on my mountain bike (the front wheel is significantly further away compared to my road bike). And there isn’t the significant energy stored up in a stretched out bungee. I highly recommend.

title: Efficient and Durable Pedals text: These are very nice lightweight yet durable pedals that allow you to get a lot more out of your cycling workouts. One side of the pedal features a standard flat platform that is similar to what you would find on a traditional bicycle. The other side has a clip-in mechanism that attaches to a cleat in your shoe.

The cleat is compatible with most types of cycling shoes. It's a standard SPD style cleat and this pedal set includes everything you need for installation. The pedals are compatible with most crank arms and will also work on most exercise bicycles.

This is a very nice pair of dual platform pedals that are perfect for teaching people how to use a clip in system. It's easy to click in and release from the pedals, and you can use the other side of the platform even when you're wearing shoes with cleats. This set of pedals will allow you to ride faster and with greater efficiency.

title: Seems to help my girl with her summer itching!
text: I wasn't expecting this to have much effect, but it really helps my 14-year-old to an amazing degree when we have to be in the heat for a little while. Even more important to me, she's been itching like mad this week and developing hot spots, and all the usual remedies (Benedryl, expensive hydrocortizone shampoo) weren't providing much, if any, relief. I tried putting on the cooling vest (wet) even though we were inside a cool house, and after a little while, she stopped itching almost completely. This effect lasted through the night (I kept it on her dry at that point) and into today. The peaceful picture I've attached shows a dramatic change from the last several days. I don't know whether it's the cooling effect or the comfort of the vest, but I'm thrilled!! Worth every penny.

Cons:
* The existing paddles are way too short!

Pros:
* Cheap
* Kayak itself feels solid and performs great

Tips:
* Buy longer paddles
* Tape down the upper seams which are sharp
* Use the tail fin! It greatly aids maneuverability

title: Great Cheap Bike Lock - Just what I needed
text: I only needed a lock that I could use when I was riding my bike to lunch or dinner in downtown Denver since most other bike rides I'm not leaving my bike unattended.  This is a great simple lock if you just want a nice deterrent to keep someone from snatching your bike.  It was easy to code and fits on my blue bike nicely.  It is just long enough to wrap through the front tire and frame and loop through a bike rack.  I never plan to leave my bike out of my site and for the price, it just gives me enough peace of mind that no one will snatch it and run off.  I wouldn't recommend this to anyone who plans to leave a bike unattended in an unsafe area, but since I store my bike in my garage and don't lock my bike up unattended in unsafe areas, this lock is exactly what I needed.  Don't fool yourself and buy this if you plan to look your bike up for long periods of time outside, someone could easily snip through this cable if they were on the prowl.

title: Very meh after firmware update text: It’s okay. It isn’t that accurate with heart rate tracking though... I have had my HR in the 150’s and the Fitbit didn’t record it and my top HR for the day will only show as 120. I have also seen my HR be in the low 70’s, and the Fitbit doesn’t record that either, it will record 81 or so. The syncing with the app is horrendous, it sometimes takes me up to 10 tries to get the Fitbit to sync.. usually I will just get a message that it failed to sync. It doesn’t track steps very well either because just moving my arm sometimes gives me up to 10 steps.. I also have it set to distance and NOT steps, so it shouldn’t be doing that. I was about to return the Fitbit, but I was a few days late so now I am stuck with it. In the future, I would save up the extra money to get a better model as this one just really isn’t that great.
The sleep tracking is pretty good... and it is usually spot on with the heart rate, but doesn’t record it properly after the firmware update.

title: What is that? text: It's been a while now, but products coming out of China are starting to rival top quality manufacturing elsewhere. This scope is a clear sign of that. The coating is smooth with no blemishes, the glass is properly and evenly multi-coated, the reticle is straight, and knobs give you decent feedback on the turns, and the flaps have tastefully relieved SIG logo on the inside (so when you flip them open EVERYONE can see what you working with [as if it matters] but still cool). The throw lever had some blemishes on it and wasn’t screwed all the way in. The Box it comes in is very simplistic – a good thing – with minimal packaging and waste. Even the handkerchief is a nice quality and small, not like grandma’s undies that sometimes come with other scopes. I also dig on the reticle shape which reminds me of an orthodox cross – it’s not too thin or thick, just the way you’d like it (is what she said, yeah, I know…). Also, looking inside the scope with super high lumen light reveals, dare I say, precision – something unexpected at this cost level. I think Sig’s trying to introduce these in the best light possible so as to grab market share. Well, their marketing is your win (for now at least)
But wait, what’s that thing on the side, looks like scribbles or some kind – what IS that?! Meatballs with wafting smell coming off them? Frog eyes? Female crocodile cartoon eyes peeking just above the surface of the water… Let me get closer… Nah, it’s a STAG! With tiny little red beady eyes. And deformed horns. WHO thought of this logo?! Watsamadderwidu?! It’s possible the weirdest logo I’ve ever come across – it’s like slapping flame prints on a Bentley. Iiiish…
But then again, who cars, the paint doesn’t drive the car. So with that little minus, I’d say Sig’s again a winner. BTW, remember the old Nikon Buckmaster scopes? They were totally awesome maaaaaan… But then Nikon got out of the biz, so I’m wondering if there’s any connection between Sig’s Buckmasters and the Nikon Buckmaster series. Whatever the case, I highly recommend this scope. (and if you don’t like the logo, put tape over it!)

title: I'm Not Quite Sure How to Review This! :-) text: I was born in the 1950s, did elementary school in the 1960s, and actually didn't get a bike until age 15 because my Dad was afraid crazy drivers would run me down. (I gained about 10 pounds when I went through puberty and my doctor was always railing about it; when I got about fifteen I finally got sneaky and told the doctor I might lose some weight if I had a bike to ride with my friends. It worked! And I did lose the weight, eventually.) Anyway, no one back then ever thought of bike helmets. I rode my bike until I moved away from home in 1984 without every donning a helmet. Hubby and I bought bikes a few years ago and when we did ride them it was around the neighborhood and we didn't think of helmets then, either. After that, our two bikes stayed trapped in the back of our garage for a few years. Well, I retired this year and "decanted" my bike and pumped up the tires and got used to riding it again, and now that it's cool again would like to start riding it, but thought about this helmet thing. But I'd never used one.

So I don't know thing one about bike helmets. This seems sturdy enough to cradle my head if I did take a header. It's made of some hard foam. It has an adjustable strap in the back (maybe all helmets have this) to make it fit snugly to my head, and out of the box the chin strap fit perfectly. But boy I didn't realize how snug a bike helmet has to fit. With it cupped on my head properly and with the chin strap on it practically makes me claustrophobic. I had to take it off after about five minutes. But this is not the bike helmet's fault.

I would say this is a nice standard bike helmet. It's plain black, but If I want to jazz it up I could put on stickers or paint it. I would say it is a good buy. Someone else who has worn these things for years will be able to tell you more.

title: Efficient and Easy to Use text: This air pump compressor allows you to get a lot more enjoyment out of your inflatable stand up paddle board. The hand pump that is typically included with an inflatable board is efficient, but it takes a long time to get up to pressure. With this unit, you simply have to connect the compressor to the valve and push a button.

I like to go out on the river with my wife and my two daughters and this compressor makes it a lot easier to get organized. There is always a lot that has to be arranged, so it's nice to be able to plug in the compressor and attend to other things while the board inflates. This compressor can go as high as 16 PSI, but I usually run my paddle boards at around 7 PSI. The automatic shut off provides the assurance that you won't have an accidental over inflation.

The compressor includes a variety of valve heads so this compressor can be used with various types of inflatables. It's a compact unit that you can conveniently store in the trunk of your car. This is a great product that will help you enjoy more quality time out on the water.

title: Easy to use, quiet, losing some weight. UPDATE April 2012 text: First - my husband put this together with a minimal of cursing and stomping. That was a good sign from minute one.
Second - it's sturdy enough that when I fell off the first time I got on it, the machine did not tumble down on top of me.
Third - it's easy to use once you get a feel for the balance and the movement.
Fourth - it's really very quiet. You can use it in front of the television wtihout driving everyone else crazy turning up the volume or having to listen to your Gazelle squeaking behind them.
Fifth - Change up your leg position (squat, bend, really stretch out) and speed up & slow down throughout your workout time and you WILL get your heart rate going and you WILL work up a sweat & burn some real calories. Watch the computer that comes with it. In the two weeks we've had this thing, I've been using it every day, gradually building up the distance from a 1/4 of a mile to a full mile per day now and I've lost 5lbs already.
Bottom line... I would buy this machine again and I am giving one to my sister for her birthday.
**************** 3 Year Update April 2012 *************************

I still use the gazelle pretty often and after three years, it's taken a beating in our house and still works smoothly, quietly and easily. The only complaint I have is that the little computer thing that tells you distance etc is no longer working accurately, but then again, after three years I guess that is to be expected. I would still buy the Gazelle if I had to do it again!

title: Absorbent, not too tight, stay put text: I tried many headbands for my cardio workouts. These really work for keeping the sweat off my face, and even help to keep my hair dry.
I typically wear a ponytail for workouts, so I didn't try to use them to keep hair in place.
They are quite absorbent and not too hot.
I just wish they had them in other colors and patterns. Not too many choices. These are very basic, but I guess they'll do for now.

title: Hands down best.
text: I know a lot of folks have left reviews of this one. I just wanted to add, you can fit it inside a backpacking cook pot. If you have a canister for fuel, put all you cooking stuff in the pot with the fuel, then remove the gsi cup lid, turn it upside down and slide it into the pot to form a lid of sorts on your cook set. If you are using alcohol or other fuel put it all in the mug and put the mug inside your pot. Perfect addition for coffee people.

These cleats are identical to the ones that I received with my Shimano SPD pedals. You simply screw them into place on the bottom of your riding shoes and you're good to go. title: Just like the Speed Ropes from the Gym text: Ok, I have to admit that I'm out of shape and late to the Crossfit world. Until starting Crossfit, I had not jumped rope in at least 30 years and it is taking me some time to get back to form. So I absolutely love having my own rope at home to try to get to double unders (right now I can finally do 30-40 single unders at a time.)

I love that these are adjustable, but at 6'4" i'm not really doing much adjusting, just leaving it at the longest setting. But they do adjust, again, just like the ones at the gym. The handles are fine, the cable has enough weight to swing well and freely. All in all, very happy with this rope and glad I can work on this away from the eyes at the gym.

title: Very dense foam - strong massage action text: If you have back pain like I do, you'll appreciate a good massage. This tubular looking thing is made of a very dense foam... so dense that when I first saw it, I thought it was hard plastic... but notit's not, there is some give to it. It turns out, when you place td his behind you in a chair, it's that density that keeps it holding its shape while it does its job. While I've been using it in an easy chair, I would say it could take a person's full weight without a problem.

It's got 3 speeds, but I find the lowest of the 3 is plenty strong enough to give me a good massage. If you needed something stronger, it's there.

At just under 6 inches in diameter and 13 inches long, it's a good size to slide behind yourself in an easy chair. There's a handle on one end that snaps out to reveal the recharging port, and on the other hand is the 3 position knob to control the speed. Of course, it comes with a charger.

The only downside is that with its dense foam and strong massage, it seems a little jarring if you try using it on your neck. Some kind of cushion would definitely be in order for that.

title: Great For Scouting
text: I'm a Scoutmaster and a Cub Scout Leader, so I do a lot of camping.  Some times I take a huge tent that they call a hotel and other times I need a backpacking tent.  This one is a good in-between.  It says 8, and it would sleep 8 if you don't use sleeping bags and don't bring any gear.  I'd say it's comfortable for 4 to 5 assuming you're related, but if you're just friends then you may want to limit to 3.  For me, I can use this by myself when the older kids are in their own tent, or with my little ones if they come along.  And although it isn't an instant up, it also can be done by two people with little experience so long as they read the instructions well.

title: Good quality at an entry-level price text: I purchased this and the chocolate one and have been pleased with both purchases. This hat is on par with similar brands selling for twenty bucks more, so the value is there. Also, the fit of the S sizes that I purchased is exactly 6 7/8, although my wife has no issues wearing them either and her size is 6 3/4.

The hatband is fixed, so changing bands will require some 'surgery', but since I purchased these as everyday, knock-around head gear that is not an issue for me.

The brim can be reshaped with a little steam, and will hold its shape. The inner sweat band is what I would call minimalist, but functional. The colors of the actual hats are close to the product photos, and the price makes this a no-brainer if you are looking for a decent, inexpensive hat that shares quality with more expensive ones on the market.

title: Fine Rod; Packaged Very Well text: Note: There are several products attached to this listing. I am specifically writing this review for the 6' light-to-moderate fast action rod.

I selected this rod to go with a new reel I have, with the intention of hitting the lake and going after largemouth bass. This has proven to be a nice rod that has worked out well for me.

When this rod arrived, it came in a heavy cardboard tube and was secured inside with foam rubber. Most rods I have ordered online come in a plastic wrap and packed in a light cardboard box. This was a huge surprise but was positive - the likelihood of this rod getting damaged in shipping is very low.

The rod is in two section (which is typical) and it assembles as expected and in negligible time. When fully assembled the rod is 6' as advertised. Attaching the reel I had in mind was minimal effort too, and I was ready to go to the lake in less than 10 minutes.

The eyes in the rod provide little to no resistance to the line during the cast. I have dealt with rods that hinder the cast; this one does not.

This is a sensitive rod and I have had no issues feeling when the fish hit. Being light to medium, pulling in a good-sized fish is a bit of work but it's not any more difficult than other rods of this type I have used.

It seems to be made well and I have found no problems with damage to the rod, loose eye ties, or a loose cuff for the reel which I have seen with some rods. With proper care this rod should last for several years.

I have not had this rod long but so far all indicators are good. It seems to be made well, it was very definitely packaged well, and it performs nicely. It is reasonably priced too.

title: WOW This Is A Nice Pillow- I Hope Smell Goes Away text: We have recently had to put together an overnight kit for my car or anyone else in the family due to an extended family illness. At any time we may have to stay overnight (it is not near our home) so I want to be sure to have what we need for those unexpected nights. I have managed to get an inflatable bed at the home, and a sleeping bag, but I wanted a nice memory foam pillow that could be used. This pillow seems just right. Let's talk about it..

WHAT IS THIS PILLOW LIKE?
This pillow comes in a package about the size of a large can of Juicy Juice or Pineapple Juice. It has a drawstring that closes it. What it is is folded upon itself. When the pillow is pulled out of its own pocket, it expands to a perfect personal sized pillow. One side is flocked and the other side is nylon feeling fabric like you would find in a winter jacket that is not slick but woven.

HOW DOES IT PERFORM?
This pillow is PERFECT. It has shredded foam inside of it but it is under filled so you can move it around to fit your head and neck. I LOVE that feature. It is just right for me as I need an under filled pillow.

SMELL
The only problem with this is that it smells really heavily of chemicals. I am not sure if it is pesticides like they use in warehouses, or if it is just chemicals from production. I hope it fades because so far it is pretty strong.

THE BOTTOM LINE
This pillow folds up to a pretty small size. When open it is a perfect size for personal sleeping, and it is easy to shift the stuffing around to make room for the head and neck support without being too firm. My only difficulty with it is the smell. If it goes away, then it will be perfect.

MY RATING
FIVE STARS. I really hope the smell goes away because it is pretty intense, but I will assume it will. If anything changes, I will try to remember to update the rating and comment to let you know.

title: Big deck is great for a street riding returning beginner like me. Big wheels roll over debris text: I'm closer to 50 years old than 40 I haven't skated since ALF was on TV but I have been eyeing the new style boards for a while now. I chose the long board style because it seemed better for riding around the neighborhood & I hoped no one would expect me to do tricks on it. As a returning rider who has been out of touch for a few decades I can't expertly critique the board but I am thoroughly enjoying it & it has good features for a street board. My daughter's boyfriend borrowed it to take to the park so it must have the right look.
This board is big. At 41", it comes up to my belt when stood on end and gives a stable ride but takes a lot of space to turn. It also seems wider than I remember from my '80s boards & there is a lot of space to move around. The wheels are about 2 3/4" in diameter which is good for rough pavement & rolling over pebbles & even the occasional stick. It's heavier than my old boards which is good for riding if not carrying.
I'm still getting the hang of "pumping" the board but kicking it is certainly faster than walking & a good reason to get out & around the neighborhood. I tightened the trucks to make them stiffer while I get used to it but I always preferred stiffer trucks anyway.
The deck is thick, 1/2" plywood, the top is completely covered with good grip tape & the bottom is painted. It has some concavity which helps to turn. The edges of the plywood are stained & look great except the scratches I have put on the ends. Despite the thickness & concavity, the deck flexes a lot due to the distance between the trucks. I don't know how normal this is since it is my first longboard. It's probably exacerbated by me tightening the trucks.

title: A lot of fun for the kids and me fairly easy to learn is heavy & robust The name brand is reassuring text: My daughter had been wanting a Hoverboard so I was pleased with how excited she still was to receive this 4 years after asking for one. She had it un-boxed and riding around the living room within minutes. It took me less than 5 minutes to stand on it and creep it around the room. Within half an hour I was speeding around the dining room table and doing figure 8s and spins on the hardwood. With the large, rubber wheels & self-balancing, I believe that it is easier to learn than a skateboard. I feel much safer getting a name-brand Hoverboard & not a cheap copy from the mall.

It handles the hardwood great & hasn't left any marks on the floor. We wipe off the tires after it has been used outside to keep any rocks or such it may have picked up from marring the floor but I haven't noticed anything stuck in the treads when cleaning them. Sometimes when turning sharply, the unloaded, outside wheel will spin a little giving the rider a bit of a start.

We don't have carpets to try it on but with the large wheels, I don't think it would slow it down much. We do use it on a bumpy, brick floor which is more challenging but it does well. The base boards in the house have taken a bit of a beating and the paint transferred to the board (see picture).

The board has a lot of lights on both sides and they actually help navigate in a dark room. I'm not sure whether it has a front & back since it doesn't seem to matter from which end it is boarded and it goes just as well in either direction. With the app, the lights can be changed to flash, strobe, stay on or flash to music played over it's speakers.

Speaking of the speakers,it would sound better just coming from the rider's phone rather than under their feet. The speakers sound like they are in a metal can but it may have more to do with their non-ideal, floor-level location than the quality of the speakers. You do have the option of syncing the flashing lights to the music which is a neat effect.

The board is heavy! It may help to stabilize it but it is not very portable. It takes a couple of hours to charge. I think it lasts about 2 hours on a charge but it's hard to say since we haven't ever run it non-stop & my daughter doesn't always wait until it is fully charged.

The app allows it to be set in "beginner", "intermediate" or "expert" mode. It comes defaulted to "expert". I wish I had known earlier, it surely would have been easier to learn on one of the slower settings.

This has been a lot of fun. We have enjoyed riding it around, challenging each other to do tasks & tricks and just standing on it while watching TV. I would love to be able to use it at the airport.

title: A Great Addition To The Workout text: I am using this product with a ProForm Performance 400 Treadmill. I am a walker, not a runner.

Out of the box, it was obvious that this was going to be an easy installation. I slid the end of the straps out of the clasp, threaded them through the back piece, and wrapped them around the console. After closing the clasps, I adjusted the strap lengths to position the back piece on the top of the console.

There was a bit of a hurdle to properly secure the shelf. There is no hinge in the shelf. Instead, you adjust the point where the shelf rests on the back piece's support. It can be a little tricky, but I did not have much trouble getting the shelf to be horizontal. Total time including removing the shelf, reading the instructions a second time to clarify some points and installing it properly was 15 seconds.

The support seems good. I placed a Dell XPS laptop on the shelf. I was able to secure it with the strap, and the shelf felt stable. I was playing movies most of the time, but I also did some typing and scrolling with the touch pad. I was also easily able to partially close the laptop to see the top of the console.

PROS:
Easy installation
Works as advertised
No need to make your own shelf that may or may not work
Good size to provide solid support to even large laptops
Easily adaptable to many exercise machines

CONS:
A bit pricy for what you get, but then you save time and money making a shelf
Obscures the console, but I can still reach under the shelf to get to the controls okay
I do not see it working well with a tablet
The strap that holds the laptop covers some of the controls and keyboard (YMMV on this one)

OVERALL:
This was a good buy. This should be something that I use daily for years.

title: well worth it if you have access to lakes and places to paddle text: Awesome.

These are nicely molded polyetheylene kayaks. They're light (because they're small), durable, and super easy to paddle.

These are easy even for kids to paddle. Although they're best for just having fun, we've gone distances with them too. My 8 year old can keep up with my canoe paddling a mile. I tow my 7 year old some of the time. After the first mile, I've towed both (as a train).

Flotation is good, especially since they have foam in both ends. They're not easy to swamp, but they certainly won't sink. They are not easy to re-enter, but this is something that takes skill with any boat. My boys have been successful re-entering several times, but it can be difficult and there has been times they failed without help. Always wear a life jacket, and never go alone.

It comes with a styrofoam billet in the front which adds extra flotation. It's a good idea, but not durable as kids will kick it with their feet down there and it will come apart (it's just white styrofoam). I removed the billets (from two kayaks) and replaced them with Polyform A-0 buoys secured to an eyebolt. I replaced the lag screw that holds the billets in with an eyebolt. The foam in the stern is unreachable and unlikely to be damaged. I wonder if it could hold muck in there, but haven't had an issue so far.

My wife at 5'1" and 100 pounds fits these nicely but a boat with slightly more leg room would be a little better. They easily hold her weight though. Even I fit them at 5'8" and 140 pounds, but I am really too big to fit the short length. I can fully straighten my legs, but my feet are all the way to narrow part of the bow. My weight causes the bow to ride too low in the water. Old Towne limits them to 100 to 115 pounds, which is about right. I would also put the height limit at 5 feet, but a heavier and taller person can fit in a pinch.

Because I have paddled these myself, I can say they are a delight to paddle. They're very fast and efficient, and they turn well. Of course they're very short and narrow for my size, so that is not surprising. However, I would not want a wider, longer boat for my boys as it would be harder to paddle and harder to turn.

They're expensive compared to cheaper two-piece or sit-on-top kayaks carried by stores that sell lots of cheap imports. I think they're worth it, especially if you have the opportunity to do a significant amount of paddling with your kids. They're probably too expensive for a beach toy that you use for a once a year trip. We've been paddling with them at least 7 times in the last two months since we got them, and will probably go another 7 times in the next two months before winter.

I paddle a canoe myself so I can fit my wife and I and our dog, plus any cargo we want. The canoe is a lot of fun too but has tradeoffs. It is harder to paddle. It is much more affected by wind. It is a beast to carry (it's an Old Towne and polyethylene also, about 80 pounds). Even though it is a smaller canoe (14'7") I could fit my family of four, our big dog, and some cargo in it. Even so, I think it was well worth it to get the kids their own boats. They have far more fun and its more motivating for them to go.

title: for extra long term storage, add flavor and texture, good to have options to choose from text: I buy Augason products when they are on sale. Been doing this on and off for a few years now. Always been a bit of a "prepper", since I was a toddler it seems, haha (In my 40s now). I has served me well through power outages, sicknesses, unemployment, and even bigger stuff like the pandemic, and now... *vaguely gestures around* everything else that is going on. I've never been one to be without when anything has come up. I never did "emergency food" if only because I didnt have the budget. I would stick with typical foods and try to store them well. Well now I have a little more wiggle room in my budget, and with the on and off sales of long term storage (20+ years), I take advantage when I can. I remember buying some Augason eggs back in 2019 for $19. Today? $33-56 for same container, depending on the day. So yeh, keep an eye on prices, buy on sale. If just starting skip the "emergency" food, and just work on picking up extra cans and bags of stuff every time you hit the market. Food lasts a whole lot longer than what the "expiration date" claims. No need to fuss. Just store in cool dark area, and from personal experience nothing really goes bad bad. Except acidic products where you want to rotate those out. Or ground brown grains, as the oils can get gross. But even pasta and flour has been perfectly fine for several years without fuss. That being said, if you are at point that you want to buy it and forget it, then buying some emergency cans and buckets of food can take the guess workout. Hence, products like what Augason Farms offers.

And so, I haven't opened this 2lbs 6 ounce can of "chicken" crumbles.. sorry. I dont intend to open this any time soon. My can looks good, and it feels heavy. All goof. I have quite a bit of bagged stuff to get through first, and I will likely continue to top off from stuff I get to store, then simply know I have this as back up to the back up. I'm not vegan nor vegetarian, but I have no problem incorporating some meat alternatives. I simply eat everything and so I stack my pantry depicting this. Options are good! And with this, I wanted to shore up my non meat options. Having this, and some veggies, some soups and biscuiot mixes, etc.. all can lend to a good meal.

I have a slew of reviews to write on various Augason products, and so they will all be pretty much the same: Super long term storage (25+ years, unless a bread/biscuit mix then it might be closer to 10 years), no matter what the weight, it will be stuffed into a #10 can (that reads, "number ten", not ten pound. I see that mistake in reviews). They keep sizes uniform. Next size up is a round bucket, next size up gets into the rectangular buckets. This is for storage that can be uniform, etc. So yes, you may buy a 7 ounce item that is volume wise that takes up a smidge of space, but it will be packed into a large #10 container. Just remember, all food products are sold based on weight, not volume anyway. All of my containers have been in perfect condition. Maybe one day soon I will try one container out and see how the product actually is.

Everyone's SHTF scenario varies. It could be bad weather (tornadoes, hurricanes, blizzards, ice storms), could be illness, could be road trip gone wrong (you do keep supplies in your car too, right?!), could be unemployment, or power outage, or lack of transportation, or oven/fridge/other appliance break down, or bigger stuff like plagues, food shortages, supply chain issues, *cough WW3 cough*, etc. No matter the situation we all need some things to get by: we need is food, water, shelter, some hygeine and medical stuff, and so on. You dont have to stack "emergency supplies" but you do need to stack shelf stable food items. Buy a few extra things every single time you go to the store. If you get to a spot that you feel comfortable and have the budget, then grab the "emergency" items like Augason offers. I like adding it in and just forgetting about it.

I give 5 stars because the cans always are in perfect condition, they have regular sales, are good about shipping items as soon as they can, have lots of items to choose from, and so far seem to be of good quality.

title: Superficial review from a beginner text: This racket is a step up from the $20 rackets that one can purchase from Target, but being a beginner, I'm uncertain how heavily my review should weigh on your decision to purchase this racket.

Compared to the cheaper racket that I previously purchased, it is slightly heavier but it seems to be of a more rugged build. The sides are well reinforced and the string is well strung. The grip is nicely cushioned and the racket is very aerodynamic; it is almost silent, lacking the whipping sound when swinging the racket. The included bag and vibration dampener are also welcome.

I hope to use this racket to learn Tennis and I believe this racquet will serve me well.

title: Great bat, added 20-30 feet to my sons distance. text: For a full review please check out generationXdad

This will be my sons last year of playing machine pitch, next year we move up to kid pitch. Last year we used an aluminum baseball bat, it wasn't bad but I did notice that kids with composite bats seemed to be hitting the ball much further.

Composite bats have a high "trampoline effect," meaning that the ball comes off faster because of the material used in the bat. When a ball hits a traditional wood bat, it gets compressed before taking off, and loses energy in the process, so it comes out more slowly. In a metal or composite bat, the bat compresses instead, so the ball retains most of its energy and flies off at a higher speed.

Additionally, the carbon fiber of composite bats actually becomes more flexible with each hit. Their ability to compress goes up, and the balls fly off faster and faster.

So this year we decided to pick up a new composite bat for the season. After reading reviews and talking to a few parents we decided to go with the Miken Rev-Ex.
If you spend a little time looking at composite bats you’ll find there’s a lot of options out there that range in price from $150 to $300+. I definitely didn’t want to spend over $200 for a baseball bat. Miken came in at the price point I was looking for. We pulled the trigger and purchased the bat from Amazon (points, points, points)

Because of this you should check with the league your child plays in and make sure that composite bats are allowed. We play in Babe Ruth, composite bats are still allowed, however Little League only allows approved bats (This bat is on their approved list).

The first day my son started using the Miken Rev-Ex I noticed a difference in how far he could hit the ball. I would guess he added a solid 20 to 30 feet in distance to his solid hits. I also notice that balls hit in the infield were like bullets! Any solid hit off this bats comes off with speed!

So far my son has been very happy with the Miken Rev-Ex and has been taken extra care of it!

Final Review: For the price and performance I’m very happy with the improvements that I have seen. I can’t speak to warranty and hope that I never need to. If you’re looking for a good fairly priced composite bat then I recommend the Miken Rev-Ex.
Being an Amazon Prime member I had the bat in two days. First thing I noticed was the warning label on the bat.

title: Great Set For Us When We Travel- VERY Versatile text: When I saw this set, I got very excited. We had planned to spend a week at a cabin where the water was not that great. We go for a lot of walks and have brought our own water to drink while we are at the cabin, but it is a hassle when going for walks to bring all of our water. Then I saw this kit-- Let's take a look.

WHAT IS THIS KIT LIKE?
This kit is very versatile. It comes with a variety of ways to use it for clean water.

SCREW ON TOP FOR PLASTIC/GLASS BOTTLES
I know, this is for walks and travel so glass is not practical. I included it here because I liked to keep the bottle in the fridge when we were not walking so that I could have cooler water in glass. However, once I tried to use it, I realized it won't work. You need to have the container draw in when pushing the water through the filter, and glass is rigid.

The bottles I used for plastic are a Polar Seltzer bottle that is a liter. It is easy to carry and is larger for a bigger water supply. I also used it in the fridge when not hiking for a solid supply of water.

BAG
If you want to have a truly portable device, there is the bag. It is also a liter and it collapses for easy transport and then when you want to fill it with water, you can and use it to drink. There is a threaded top that goes on the pouch to attach the spout to, or you can cover it up completely to carry with you if not intending to use right away.

STRAW
You can also use this by attaching the straw that comes with the package to the end of the filter and put it in a container of water to drink.

INLINE FILTER
If you plan to do a lot of hiking and have a backpack that you use for water, this can be used inline. I have not used it for that yet, but plan to test it out on a hike this summer.

HOW DOES THIS PERFORM?
This performs very well. I have to say that I did not expect it to work as well as it does. It is a bit tricky to get the water to get up through the filter at first because the filter requires some suction to pass the water through so it can be filtered. Once you realize that, it is not as frustrating. The water we used appeared to be clean (in other words not muddy) and it worked out nicely.

TASTE
This definitely improves taste, even from tap water at the cabin which was not the greatest. It does a pretty good job.

WHAT ABOUT MUDDY WATER?
Call me a baby. Go ahead. I can not bring myself to use this in muddy water, even to test it. Perhaps if I am desperate I will do that, and then I can update this review. Until then, well, I am sure some other brave person will have given you their results on it in the meanwhile.

CLEANING
That is the frustration of this filter. We don't use it constantly, so there comes a time when you have to run bleach water through the unit and in the pouch if you use that before storing. It has to sit for a while and then air dry. You use the enclosed syringe and ring and backwash the filter and pouch with water that includes a capful of bleach. I understand why this has to happen, but air drying takes quite a while and when I first go to use the unit again later, it tastes like bleach which I despise.

After a while it rinses out, but I really don't like that part.

THE BOTTOM LINE
For a great set which really does help for hiking in an area where there might not be great water, this is handy to have. It is easy to clean and although I am not fond of the bleach method, I know why it must be done for future use.

MY RATING
FIVE STARS. I love having this for our cabin stays. It makes it so we can drink water out on the trails and not have to worry about it being unsafe. I plan to get a 2nd one for my husband so we can each have our own. I also like having it in the cabin to run through the water in there as I have not been overly sure of it in the past.

title: I like this fly text: I liked this fly after watching a few videos online. I decided to purchase the HouseFly vs. others. I loved that it has ends that can be closed off or rolled back, and the larger size of the HouseFly was my main reason for purchasing it.

I received mine yesterday and promptly went about setting it up outside. I wanted a fair test before heading out on the trail. Last night was a superb choice as it was to rain, and it did. I remained totally dry. I needed the unpack and set up once before heading out, and I recommend that to anyone. It helped wipe out some rough edges on my setup technique.

Setup was easy for my first time. We worked at a rather moderate pace, especially when my 8-year old wanted to help put in the stakes for the tie-down ropes. The stakes are not included in the fly and must be purchased separately. I chose the orange-colored fly over the green as it makes the fly easier seen. After setting up my fly, I promptly forgot the first rule, walk further away from the tie-down cordage and stakes. Where I immediately tripped myself up.

I was not rather impressed with the included tie-down cordage. It is rather stiff, and I prefer ropes which are easily bendable and packable. Not to mention easier to stake out. So, I will be replacing the cordage with some paracord with a softer, more pliable body. This is the first real con I have had with ENO products. But to be totally fair to them, I almost always find that cordage included with a product doesn't live up to my personal desires/expectations. You may find the cordage fine and have no issue with it. I also wanted a slightly longer length on the ridge ties. The cordage may be fine after some initial usage, but in my usage, the cordage was just as stiff upon taking down the fly as it was putting it up.

I would still repurchase the HouseFly in a moment, with or without the cordage. I will indeed be buying it again for the wife and her hammock, though I think I'll choose a green or blue version for her. Doing so will allow me to switch out my color as my mood fits. I'll likely buy something smaller for the kids.

Oh, It's rather large, I think we could safely hang side by side under the fly.

edit 12/28/2017

Yes, two people can hang under the fly though I set it up slightly wider than usual. I ended up not being able to close the doors. I didn't want to adjust my setup. It rained the evening, and the fly kept up perfectly dry all night.

title: Great indoor fun! Just make sure you have enough room text: It's winter here on the east coast, and my kids need indoor activities that keep them moving! This is an INCREDIBLE fun arcade experience at home, provided you have enough room for it. Yes, it folds up which helps tremendously, however this is pretty true-to-scale arcade style game, which means you need high ceiling clearance as well. We have a guest room that we use as a home gym, and it actually wouldn't fit because the ceiling isn't high enough to shoot. Thankfully, I was able to move it out to the garage which is PERFECT. I feel like I'm very lucky to have the room for this, because my previous home had a garage under bedrooms with room-high ceilings which wouldn't have worked very well.
I DID have some difficulty building the game, as the instructions were a little bit unclear at some parts (there are at least 2 steps that could have been made a LOT clearer and saved me a lot of time backing up and redoing parts), and it doesn't come with any extra hardware so you need to really be careful not to lose of it during assembly. We had to supplement 2 washers and a bolt from parts I had around the house already because we appear to have lost some on the way. BUT- once assembled, this is great fun! title: Sturdy and Easy to Transport and Store text: I have a large backyard with a pool and since I live in a warm climate, we tend to spend to good deal of time outside, either using the pool, sitting on the patio, or playing games. We have a good number of outdoor games and when I heard about the Franklin Sports Optima All- Weather Outdoor Tennis Table, I was more than ready to add it to my household’s recreational options.

From the large box, this table tennis set does take some time to assemble, so be prepared. Once you get everything set, it is a matter of rolling the table from place to place. My garage is the present location for the table because we can use it here, when we want to play a round of table tennis inside. When we want to take it outside, it is just a matter of rolling it from the garage through the backyard gate and into the back yard.

This table tennis set is sturdy and seems like it was built to last. It is heavy, and you will realize this the moment the box arrives in the mail. But the fact that it is on wheels makes you not really notice the weight. It is easy to transport from place to place because of this and when folded, it fits into small spaces for storage. And while the table is made for outdoor use, I think it is best to make it a point to wheel it back inside or into a storage shed after each use. I debated this at first and considered just permanently leaving it outside. But then I decided it was better to make sure it lasts by protecting it from the weather.

The aluminum surface on this table tennis set is smooth and ideal for a round of table tennis. The balls bounce well on this surface and the net is easy to install and take down when you’re ready to fold the table and roll it back inside. The table is nine feet long and five feet wide so it will fit in most game rooms. Unlike a billiard table, you don’t need a lot of space on each side so it should fit in many rooms of the typical house.

Outdoor games like cornhole and croquet have been part of our backyard recreation for some time and now table tennis is part of the picture, thanks to the franklin Sports Optima All- Weather Outdoor Table Tennis Table. The ease of transporting it and the heavy- duty aluminum construction make this table tennis set a cut above the competition and a great option for people like me who spend a good deal of time outdoors.
